topic: Bachelor of Science in Office Administration - Third and Fourth Year Course Offerings

content:
The Bachelor of Science in Psychology program under the College of Arts and Sciences at the Eulogio 'Amang' Rodriguez Institute of Science and Technology (EARIST) mandates a specific curriculum for the First Year. 

During the First Semester, students are required to take the following courses totaling 25 credited units: Biological Science Laboratory (BIOSCLAB, 1 unit) and Lecture (BIOSCLEC, 4 units); Kontekstwalisadong Komunikasyon sa Filipino (GEKOMFIL, 3 units); Movement Enhancement (GEPEMOVE, 2 units); Purposive Communication (GEPURPCO, 3 units); Readings in Philippine History (GEREADPH, 3 units); Understanding the Self (GEUNDETS, 3 units); Introduction to Psychology (INTROPSY, 3 units); and National Service Training Program 1 (NSTPROG1, 3 units). None of these courses have prerequisites.

During the Second Semester, the curriculum requires 36 credited units consisting of: Anatomy and Physiology Laboratory (ANAPYLAB, 1 unit) and Lecture (ANAPYLEC, 4 units); Art Appreciation (GEARTAPP, 3 units); Mathematics in the Modern World (GEMATHMW, 3 units); Panitikan sa Pilipinas (GEPANIPI, 3 units); Fitness Exercises (GEPEFITE, 2 units); Science, Technology and Society (GESCIETS, 3 units); and Psychological Statistics (PSYCSTAT, 5 units). Additionally, students must complete the second component of the National Service Training Program (NSTPROG2, 3 units), choosing from Civic Welfare Training Service 2 (NSTP-CWTS_2), Literacy Training Service 2 (NSTP-LTS 2), or Military Training Service 2 (NSTP-MTS_2). No prerequisites are listed for these first-year courses.
category: College of Arts and Sciences - Program Offerings
topic: Bachelor of Science in Psychology First Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Science in Psychology program under the College of Arts and Sciences at EARIST outlines the following course requirements for the Second Year level.

The First Semester consists of 20 credited units comprising: Biochemistry Laboratory (BIOCHLAB, 1 unit) and Lecture (BIOCHLEC, 4 units); Developmental Psychology (DEVPSYCH, 3 units); Practical Data Science (GEELECDS, 3 units); Living in Information Technology Era (GEELECIT, 3 units); Physical Activity Towards Health and Fitness 1 (GEPEHEF1, 2 units); Sinesosyedad/Pelikulang Panlipunan (GESINEPP, 3 units); and Physiological Psychology (PHYPSYCH, 1 unit). While specific prerequisites are listed as 'None' in the summary table, these courses build upon first-year foundational sciences.

The Second Semester curriculum comprises 21 credited units. The required courses are: Experimental Psychology Laboratory (EXPSYLAB, 2 units) and Lecture (EXPSYLEC, 3 units); The Contemporary World (GECONTWO, 3 units); Communicative Proficiency in Business Correspondence and Research Writing (GEELECCP, 3 units); Physical Activity Towards Health and Fitness II (GEPEHEF2, 2 units); Physics for Psychology Students Laboratory (PHYPSYLB, 1 unit) and Lecture (PHYPSYLC, 4 units); and Theories of Personality (THEOPERS, 3 units). This year focuses heavily on the scientific and experimental foundations of the discipline.
category: College of Arts and Sciences - Program Offerings
topic: Bachelor of Science in Psychology Second Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Science in Psychology program under the College of Arts and Sciences at EARIST defines the Third Year curriculum as the period where major professional psychology courses are concentrated.

The First Semester requires a total of 20 credited units including: Abnormal Psychology (ABNPSYCH, 3 units); Cognitive Psychology (COGPSYCH, 3 units); Field Methods Laboratory (FLDMETLB, 2 units) and Lecture (FLDMETLC, 3 units); Ethics (GEETHICS, 3 units); Industrial Organizational Psychology (INDPSYCH, 3 units which includes 2 lecture and 1 lab unit); and Social Psychology (SOCPSYCH, 3 units).

The Second Semester curriculum expands to 23 credited units and includes: The Life and Works of Rizal (GELIFEWR, 3 units); Human Behavior in Organizations (HUMBEORG, 3 units); Labor Laws and Labor Relations (LABORLAW, 3 units); Disaster and Mental Health (MNTLHLTH, 3 units); Psychological Assessment Laboratory (PSYASSLB, 2 units) and Lecture (PSYASSLC, 3 units); Research in Psychology I (PSYTHES1, 3 units); and Sikolohiyang Pilipino (SIKOLPIL, 3 units). This year introduces critical research and assessment methodologies required for the final year.
category: College of Arts and Sciences - Program Offerings
topic: Bachelor of Science in Psychology Third Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Science in Psychology program under the College of Arts and Sciences at EARIST concludes with the Fourth Year curriculum, which focuses on advanced applications, research completion, and professional review.

The First Semester of the Fourth Year requires 18 credited units consisting of: Panitikan sa Pilipinas / Philippine Literature (GEPANIPI, 3 units); an Open Elective (OPENELEC, 3 units); Organizational Development (ORGLDVMT, 3 units); Positive Psychology (POSPSYCH, 3 units); Research in Psychology II (PSYTHES2, 3 units), which serves as the continuation of the thesis project; and Strategic Human Resource Management (STRATHRM, 3 units).

The Second Semester is the final academic term and consists of 10 credited units dedicated to professional preparation: Integrative Course in Psychology / Review Class (ICOPSYCH, 4 units) and the Practicum/Internship (PSYCHOJT, 6 units). 

According to the document prepared by the Department Head and attested by the Dean, the Total Number of Units required to graduate from the BS Psychology program is 173. The curriculum effectivity date is listed as June 2018.
category: College of Arts and Sciences - Program Offerings
topic: Bachelor of Science in Psychology Fourth Year Curriculum and Program Summary

content:
The Bachelor of Science in Tourism Management program under the College of Hospitality and Tourism Management at the Eulogio 'Amang' Rodriguez Institute of Science and Technology (EARIST) outlines the following curriculum for the First Year.

During the First Semester, students are required to take courses totaling 23 credited units. These include: Living in Information Technology Era (GEELECIT, 3 units, 2 lecture/1 lab); Kontekstwalisadong Komunikasyon sa Filipino (GEKOMFIL, 3 units); Movement Enhancement (GEPEMOVE, 2 units); Understanding the Self (GEUNDETS, 3 units); National Service Training Program 1 (NSTPROG1, 3 units); Macro Perspective of Tourism and Hospitality (THCMACPR, 3 units); Risk Management as Applied to Safety, Security and Sanitation (THCRISKM, 3 units); and Sustainable Tourism (TPCSUSTO, 3 units). None of these courses have prerequisites.

The Second Semester curriculum requires a total of 26 credited units (though the source table summation indicates 38, likely due to row merging in the source text). The courses include: Mathematics in the Modern World (GEMATHMW, 3 units); Panitikan sa Pilipinas (GEPANIPI, 3 units); Fitness Exercises (GEPEFITE, 2 units); Science, Technology and Society (GESCIETS, 3 units); and National Service Training Program 2 (NSTPROG2, 3 units), where students may choose between Civic Welfare (CWTS), Literacy Training (LTS), or Military Training (MTS). Major courses for this semester are: Micro Perspective of Tourism and Hospitality (THCMICPR, 3 units, Prerequisite: THCMACPR); Quality Service Management in Tourism and Hospitality (THCQUASM, 3 units, Prerequisite: THCMACPR); Global Culture and Tourism Geography (TPCGLCTG, 3 units); and Recreational and Leisure Management (TPECRELM, 3 units).
category: College of Hospitality and Tourism Management - Program Offerings
topic: Bachelor of Science in Tourism Management First Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Science in Tourism Management program under the College of Hospitality and Tourism Management at EARIST prescribes the following courses for the Second Year level.

The First Semester consists of 23 credited units. The required courses are: Physical Activity Towards Health and Fitness 1 (GEPEHEF1, 2 units); Purposive Communication (GEPURPCO, 3 units); Readings in Philippine History (GEREADPH, 3 units); and Philippine Culture and Tourism Geography (THCPHCTG, 3 units). Several major courses require prerequisites from the first year: Tour and Travel Management (TPCTTMGT, 3 units) requires THCMACPR and THCMICPR; Eco Tourism Management (TPECECTM, 3 units) requires TPCSUSTO; Specialized Food and Beverage Service Operations (TPECSFBS, 3 units) requires THCRISKM; and Tourism Information Management (TPECTINM, 3 units) requires THCMACPR and THCMICPR.

The Second Semester curriculum also consists of 23 credited units. The General Education courses are World Literature and Humanities (GEADWOLH, 3 units), The Contemporary World (GECONTWO, 3 units), and Physical Activity Towards Health and Fitness II (GEPEHEF2, 2 units). The professional courses include: Operations Management in Tourism and Hospitality (BMECOPMN, 3 units); Entrepreneurship in Tourism and Hospitality (THCENTRE, 3 units); Legal Aspects in Tourism and Hospitality (THCLEGAS, 3 units, Prerequisite: THCMACPR); Transportation Management (TPCTRANM, 3 units, Prerequisites: THCMACPR, THCMICPR, TPCTTMGT); and The Ethics of Tour Guiding and Escorting (TPECETGE, 3 units, Prerequisites: THCMACPR, THCMICPR, TPCSUSTO, TPCGLCTG, TPCTTMGT, TPECTINM).
category: College of Hospitality and Tourism Management - Program Offerings
topic: Bachelor of Science in Tourism Management Second Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Science in Tourism Management program under the College of Hospitality and Tourism Management at EARIST defines the Third Year curriculum as a period for advanced specialization and research.

The First Semester requires 24 credited units. Courses include: Practical Data Science (GEELECDS, 3 units); Ethics (GEETHICS, 3 units); and Multicultural Diversity in Workplace for the Tourism Professional (THCMULDI, 3 units). Specialized courses with prerequisites are: Tourism and Hospitality Marketing (THCMARKT, 3 units, Prerequisites: THCMACPR, THCMICPR); Foreign Language 1 (THPCFLA1, 3 units); Introduction to Meetings Incentives, Conferences and Events Management (THPCMICE, 3 units, Prerequisites: THCQUASM, THCMICPR, BMECOPMN, THCLEGAS); Research in Tourism 1 (TPCREST1, 3 units, 2 lec/1 lab); and Tourism Policy Planning and Development (TPCTPPAD, 3 units, Prerequisites: TPCSUSTO, TPCTTMGT, TPECECTM, TPECTINM, THCLEGAS).

The Second Semester also requires 24 credited units. The curriculum includes: Art Appreciation (GEARTAPP, 3 units); Professional Development and Applied Ethics (THCPDAET, 3 units); Applied Business Tools and Technologies (THPCABTT, 3 units); and Foreign Language 2 (THPCFLA2, 3 units, Prerequisite: THPCFLA1). Advanced major courses are: Research in Tourism 2 (TPCREST2, 3 units, Prerequisite: TPCREST1); Cruise Tourism (TPECCRTO, 3 units, Prerequisites: THCMACPR, THCMICPR); Destination Management and Marketing (TPECDESM, 3 units, Prerequisites: THCMARKT, TPCTTMGT, TPECTINM); and Tourism Product Development (TPECTPRD, 3 units, Prerequisite: TPCTPPAD).
category: College of Hospitality and Tourism Management - Program Offerings
topic: Bachelor of Science in Tourism Management Third Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Science in Tourism Management program at EARIST concludes with the Fourth Year curriculum, focusing on strategic management and practical application through internship.

The First Semester consists of 15 credited units. The courses are: Strategic Management and Total Quality Management (BMECSTQM, 3 units); The Life and Works of Rizal (GELIFEWR, 3 units); Accommodation Operations and Management (TPECOROM/TPECACOM, 3 units, Prerequisites: THCMACPR, THCMICPR); Philippine Gastronomical Tourism (TPECPHGT, 3 units, Prerequisites: THCMICPR, THCMACPR); and Travel Writing and Photography (TPECTWAP, 3 units, Prerequisites: THCMACPR, THCMICPR).

The Second Semester is dedicated entirely to the Tourism Practicum (TPCTORPR), which is valued at 6 credited units and requires 600 hours of duty in Transportation, Tourism Offices, Travel Agencies, or Airports. This course has an extensive list of prerequisites that effectively includes all major subjects from the previous years: THCMACPR, TPCSUSTO, THCRISKM, TPCGLCTG, TPECRELM, THCQUASM, THCMICPR, TPCTTMGT, THCPHCTG, TPECECTM, TPECSFBS, TPECTINM, TPCTRANM, THCLEGAS, THCENTRE, TPECETGE, TPCTPPAD, THCMULDI, THPCMICE, and Foreign Language 1.
category: College of Hospitality and Tourism Management - Program Offerings
topic: Bachelor of Science in Tourism Management Fourth Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Home Economics) program under the College of Education at the Eulogio 'Amang' Rodriguez Institute of Science and Technology (EARIST) outlines the following curriculum for the First Year.

During the First Semester, students are required to take courses totaling 32 credited units. The General Education and minor subjects include: Art Appreciation (GEARTAPP, 3 units); Kontekstwalisadong Komunikasyon sa Filipino (GEKOMFIL, 3 units); The Life and Works of Rizal (GELIFEWR, 3 units); Mathematics in the Modern World (GEMATHMW, 3 units); Movement Enhancement (GEPEMOVE, 2 units); Science, Technology and Society (GESCIETS, 3 units); NSTP Literacy Training Service 1 (NSTPLTS1, 3 units); and National Service Training Program 1 (NSTPROG1, 3 units). The major introductory courses are Home Economics Literacy (TLEEXHEL, 3 units); Introduction to Information and Communications Technology I (TLEEXITY, 3 units); and Consumer Education (TLEHECED, 3 units). None of these first-semester courses have prerequisites.

The Second Semester curriculum also consists of 32 credited units. The required courses are: Living in Information Technology Era (GEELECIT, 3 units, 2 lecture/1 lab); Filipino sa Iba't ibang Disiplina (GEFILDIS, 3 units); Fitness Exercises (GEPEFITE, 2 units); Purposive Communication (GEPURPCO, 3 units); Readings in Philippine History (GEREADPH, 3 units); and Understanding the Self (GEUNDETS, 3 units). The National Service Training Program continues with NSTP Literacy Training Service 2 (NSTPLTS2, 3 units, Prerequisite: NSTPLTS1) and National Service Training Program 2 (NSTPROG2, 3 units). The major courses for this semester include: Entrepreneurship (TLEEXENT, 3 units, Prerequisite: TLEEXHEL); Family and Consumer Life Skills (TLEEXFCL, 3 units, Prerequisite: TLEHECED); and Introduction to Information and Communications Technology II (TLEEXIT2, 3 units, Prerequisite: TLEEXIT1/TLEEXITY).
topic: Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Home Economics) First Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Home Economics) program under the College of Education at EARIST prescribes the following courses for the Second Year level.

The First Semester consists of 29 credited units. The curriculum includes: Communicative Proficiency in Business Correspondence and Research Writing (GEADCPBR, 3 units); The Contemporary World (GECONTWO, 3 units); Panitikan sa Pilipinas (GEPANIPI, 3 units); and Physical Activity Towards Health and Fitness 1 (GEPEHEF1, 2 units). Professional Education courses introduced in this term are The Child and Adolescent Learners and Learning Principles (PEDCALLP, 3 units) and The Teaching Profession (PEDTTPRO, 3 units). The major TLE courses are: Introduction to Agri-Fishery Arts 1 (TLEEXAF1, 3 units); Introduction to Industrial Arts I (TLEEXIA1, 3 units); Household Resource Management (TLEHEHRM, 3 units, 1 lecture/2 lab); and Principles of Food Preparation (TLEHEPFP, 3 units, 1 lecture/2 lab). No specific prerequisites are listed for this semester's courses in the provided table.

The Second Semester curriculum comprises 29 credited units. General Education requirements include Practical Data Science (GEADDPDS, 3 units), Ethics (GEETHICS, 3 units), and Physical Activity Towards Health and Fitness II (GEPEHEF2, 2 units). Professional Education courses include The Teacher and the Community, School Culture, and Organizational Leadership (PEDTCSPT, 3 units) and Technology for Teaching and Learning 1 (PEDTFTAL, 3 units). The specialized TLE courses with prerequisites are: Introduction to Agri-Fishery Arts II (TLEEXAF2, 3 units, Prerequisite: TLEEXAF1); Introduction to Industrial Arts II (TLEEXIA2, 3 units, Prerequisite: TLEEXIA1); Bread and Pastry Arts (TLEHEBPA, 3 units, Prerequisite: TLEHEPFP); Food and Nutrition (TLEHEFAN, 3 units, Prerequisite: TLEHEPFP); and School Food Service Management (TLEHESFM, 3 units, Prerequisite: TLEHEHRM), which notably includes a 150-hour Practicum Component.
topic: Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Home Economics) Second Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Home Economics) program at EARIST outlines the Third Year curriculum, focusing heavily on pedagogy and specialized home economics skills.

The First Semester requires 27 credited units. Professional Education courses include: Assessment of Learning 1 (PEDASLT1, 3 units); Facilitating Learner-Centered Teaching Approaches w/ Emphasis on Trainers Methodology I (PEDFLTM1, 3 units); Foundation of Special and Inclusive Education (PEDFOSIE, 3 units); and Technology for Teaching & Learning 2 (TLEEXTTL, 3 units, Prerequisite: PEDTFTAL). The research component begins with Research I: Research In Home Economics 1 (RESINHE1, 3 units). Major courses include: Arts in Daily Living (TLEHEADL, 3 units); Child and Adolescent Development (TLEHECAD, 3 units); Clothing Selection, Purchase & Care (TLEHECSP, 3 units); and Fundamentals of Food Technology (TLEHEFFT, 3 units).

The Second Semester consists of 24 credited units. The Professional Education component covers Assessment of Learning 2 w/ Focus on Trainer's Methodology I & II (PEDAL2TM, 3 units, Prerequisite: PEDASOL1/PEDASLT1); Building and Enhancing New Literacies Across the Curriculum (PEDBELAC, 3 units); and Curriculum Development and Evaluation w/ Emphasis on Trainers Methodology II (PEDCDTM2, 3 units). The research track continues with Research II: Research in Home Economics II (RESINHE2, 3 units, Prerequisite: RESINHE1). Specialized skills courses include Beauty Care with Health & Wellness (TLEHEBCH, 3 units); Clothing Construction (TLEHECCD, 3 units, Prerequisite: TLEHECSP); Crafts Design (TLEHECDH, 3 units); and Marriage and Family Relationships (TLEHEMFR, 3 units).
topic: Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Home Economics) Third Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Home Economics) program at EARIST culminates in the Fourth Year with a focus on field study and competency enhancement.

The First Semester lists two primary courses totaling 6 credited units. The first is Competencies Enhancement Program (PEDCOPRO, 3 units), which has no prerequisites. The second is Field Study 1 (PEDFSTDY1, 3 units). 

Field Study 1 (PEDFSTDY1) serves as a capstone requirement and has an extensive list of prerequisites encompassing nearly the entire program curriculum. Students must have completed: Assessment of Learning 2 (PEDAL2TM); Assessment of Learning 1 (PEDASOL1); Building and Enhancing New Literacies (PEDBELAC); Child and Adolescent Learners (PEDCALLP); Curriculum Development (PEDCDTM2); Facilitating Learner-Centered Teaching (PEDFLTM1); Special and Inclusive Education (PEDFOSIE); Teacher and the Community (PEDTCSPT); Technology for Teaching 1 (PEDTFTAL); The Teaching Profession (PEDTTPRO); Introduction to Agri-Fishery Arts 1 & 2 (TLEEXAF1, TLEEXAF2); Entrepreneurship (TLEEXENT); Family and Consumer Life Skills (TLEEXFCL); Home Economics Literacy (TLEEXHEL); Introduction to Industrial Arts 1 & 2 (TLEEXIA1, TLEEXIA2); ICT 1 & 2 (TLEEXIT1, TLEEXIT2); Technology for Teaching 2 (TLEEXTTL); Arts in Daily Living (TLEHEADL); Bread and Pastry Arts (TLEHEBPA); Beauty Care (TLEHEBCH); Child and Adolescent Development (TLEHECAD); Clothing Construction (TLEHECCD); Crafts Design (TLEHECDH); Consumer Education (TLEHECED); and Clothing Selection (TLEHECSP).
topic: Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Home Economics) Fourth Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Industrial Arts) program under the College of Education at the Eulogio 'Amang' Rodriguez Institute of Science and Technology (EARIST) outlines the curriculum for the First Year.

The First Semester requires a total of 32 credited units. The courses include: Art Appreciation (GEARTAPP, 3 units); Kontekstwalisadong Komunikasyon sa Filipino (GEKOMFIL, 3 units); The Life and Works of Rizal (GELIFEWR, 3 units); Mathematics in the Modern World (GEMATHMW, 3 units); Movement Enhancement (GEPEMOVE, 2 units); Science, Technology and Society (GESCIETS, 3 units); NSTP Literacy Training Service 1 (NSTPLTS1, 3 units); National Service Training Program 1 (NSTPROG1, 3 units); Home Economics Literacy (TLEEXHEL, 3 units); Introduction to Information and Communications Technology I (TLEEXITI, 3 units); and Graphic Arts (TLEIAGHA, 3 units). All courses in this semester have no prerequisites.

The Second Semester curriculum consists of 35 credited units. The required courses are: Living in Information Technology Era (GEELECIT, 3 units, 2 lec/1 lab); Filipino sa Iba't ibang Disiplina (GEFILDIS, 3 units); Fitness Exercises (GEPEFITE, 2 units); Purposive Communication (GEPURPCO, 3 units); Readings in Philippine History (GEREADPH, 3 units); Understanding the Self (GEUNDETS, 3 units); NSTP Literacy Training Service 2 (NSTPLTS2, 3 units); National Service Training Program 2 (NSTPROG2, 3 units); Entrepreneurship (TLEEXENT, 3 units); Family and Consumer Life Skills (TLEEXFCL, 3 units); and Introduction to Information and Communications Technology II (TLEEXIT2, 3 units).
topic: Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Industrial Arts) First Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Industrial Arts) program at EARIST prescribes the following courses for the Second Year level.

The First Semester consists of 29 credited units. The General Education and Professional Education courses are: Communicative Proficiency in Business Correspondence and Research Writing (GEADCPBR, 3 units); The Contemporary World (GECONTWO, 3 units); Panitikan sa Pilipinas (GEPANIPI, 3 units); Physical Activity Towards Health and Fitness 1 (GEPEHEF1, 2 units); The Child and Adolescent Learners and Learning Principles (PEDCALLP, 3 units); and The Teaching Profession (PEDTTPRO, 3 units). The major Industrial Arts courses are: Introduction to Agri-Fishery Arts 1 (TLEEXAF1, 3 units); Introduction to Industrial Arts I (TLEEXIA1, 3 units); Civil Technology I (TLEIACT1, 3 units, 1 lec/2 lab); and Fundamentals of Automotive Technology (TLEIAFAT, 3 units, 1 lec/2 lab).

The Second Semester curriculum comprises 26 credited units. The courses include: Practical Data Science (GEADDPDS, 3 units); Ethics (GEETHICS, 3 units); Physical Activity Towards Health and Fitness II (GEPEHEF2, 2 units); The Teacher and the Community, School Culture, and Organizational Leadership w/ Focus on the Philippine TVET System (PEDTCSPT, 3 units); Technology for Teaching and Learning 1 (PEDTFTAL, 3 units); Introduction to Agri-Fishery Arts II (TLEEXAF2, 3 units); Introduction to Industrial Arts II (TLEEXIA2, 3 units); Applied Automotive Technology (TLEIAAAT, 3 units, 1 lec/2 lab); and Civil Technology II (TLEIACT2, 3 units, 1 lec/2 lab).
topic: Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Industrial Arts) Second Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Industrial Arts) program at EARIST outlines the Third Year curriculum, emphasizing advanced technical skills and pedagogy.

The First Semester requires a total of 27 credited units. Professional Education courses include: Assessment of Learning 1 (PEDASLT1, 3 units); Facilitating Learner-Centered Teaching Approaches w/ Emphasis on Trainers Methodology I (PEDFLTM1, 3 units); Foundation of Special and Inclusive Education (PEDFOSIE, 3 units); and Technology for Teaching & Learning 2 (TLEEXTTL, 3 units). The research component is Research I: Research In Industrial Arts 1 (RESINIA1, 3 units). Specialized technical courses are: Domestic Refrigeration and Air-Conditioning (TLEIADRA, 3 units, 1 lec/2 lab); Fundamentals of Electronics Technology (TLEIAFEE, 3 units, 1 lec/2 lab); Fundamentals of Electrical Technology (TLEIAFET, 3 units, 1 lec/2 lab); and Metal Works (TLEIAMWS, 3 units, 1 lec/2 lab).

The Second Semester consists of 24 credited units. Courses include: Assessment of Learning 2 w/ Focus on Trainer's Methodology I & II (PEDAL2TM, 3 units); Building and Enhancing New Literacies Across the Curriculum (PEDBELAC, 3 units); Curriculum Development and Evaluation w/ Emphasis on Trainers Methodology II (PEDCDTM2, 3 units); Research II: Research in Industrial Arts II (RESINIA2, 3 units); Applied Electrical Technology (TLEIAAET, 3 units, 1 lec/2 lab); Crafts Design / Handicraft (TLEIACDH, 3 units, 1 lec/2 lab); Commercial Refrigeration and Air-Conditioning (TLEIACRA, 3 units, 1 lec/2 lab); and Digital Electronics Technology (TLEIADET, 3 units, 1 lec/2 lab).
topic: Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Industrial Arts) Third Year Curriculum

content:
The Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Industrial Arts) program at EARIST concludes with the Fourth Year curriculum, which focuses on field study and internship.

The First Semester requires 9 credited units, consisting of the Competencies Enhancement Program (PEDCOPRO, 3 units), Field Study 1 (PEDFSTDY1, 3 units), and Field Study 2 (PEDFSTDY2, 3 units). 

The Second Semester consists solely of the Teaching Internship (PEDNTERN), which is valued at 6 credited units.

The document indicates a Total Number of Units of 188 for the entire program, with an effectivity date of June 2018. It is prepared by the Head and attested by the Dean of the College of Education.
topic: Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (Industrial Arts) Fourth Year Curriculum and Program Summary

content:
According to the EARIST Admission Posters for Academic Year 2025-2026, the University has established specific grade and general weighted average (GWA) requirements for its technical, engineering, and design colleges. 

The College of Engineering (CEN) enforces the most rigorous admission standards. Applicants for the Bachelor of Science degrees in Chemical Engineering (BSChE), Electrical Engineering (BSEE), Civil Engineering (BSCE), Mechanical Engineering (BSME), Computer Engineering (BSCoE), and Electronics and Communication Engineering (BSECE) must possess a General Weighted Average (GWA) of 90% or above and must have no grades lower than 88 in all subjects. For official inquiries, the College of Engineering operates via https://www.facebook.com/CENSGEARIST.

The College of Computing Studies (CCS) offers the Bachelor of Science in Computer Science (BSCS) and the Bachelor of Science in Information Technology (BS INFO.TECH). The admission policy mandates that applicants must have no grades lower than 80 in all subjects and must achieve a GWA of 90% or above. The official communication channel for CCS is https://www.facebook.com/tatakComsa.

The College of Architecture and Fine Arts (CAFA) has distinct criteria for its programs. The Bachelor of Science in Architecture (BS ARCHI.) and Bachelor of Science in Interior Design (BSID) require no grades lower than 85 in all subjects and a GWA of 90%. Alternatively, the Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA), offering majors in Painting and Visual Communication, requires a GWA of 85%. The official CAFA page is located at https://www.facebook.com/cafaearistofficial.

The College of Industrial Technology (CIT) offers the Bachelor of Industrial Technology with a wide range of majors including Apparel and Fashion Technology, Automotive Technology, Computer Technology, Drafting Technology, Electrical Technology, Electronics Technology, Food Trades, Industrial Chemistry, Mechanical Technology, and Heating, Ventilating and Air-Conditioning Technology. The unified qualification for all CIT majors is that applicants must have no grades lower than 80 in all subjects. The official CIT page is accessible at https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100076321872710&sk=about.
source: EARIST Admission Posters A.Y. 2025-2026 & Social Media Directory
topic: Requirements for Engineering, Computing, Industrial Tech, and Architecture (CEN, CCS, CIT, CAFA)

content:
According to the EARIST Admission Posters for Academic Year 2025-2026, the University has updated the admission criteria for its business, social science, and service-oriented programs. 

The College of Business and Public Administration (CBPA) offers the Bachelor of Science in Office Administration (BSOA), Bachelor of Science in Business Administration (Majors in Marketing Management, Human Resource Management), Bachelor of Science in Entrepreneurship (BSEntrep), and Bachelor of Science in Public Administration (BPA). Applicants to these programs must have no grades lower than 80 in all subjects and a General Weighted Average (GWA) of 90% or above. The official CBPA page is https://www.facebook.com/earist.cbpa.

The College of Criminal Justice Education (CCJE) offers the Bachelor of Science in Criminology (BSCrim). This program has strict physical and academic requirements: applicants must have no grades lower than 85 in all subjects, a GWA of 90% or above, and must meet the height requirement of 5'0" for females and 5'2" for males. The official CCJE page is https://www.facebook.com/EARIST.CCJE.

The College of Hospitality and Tourism Management (CHTM) offers the Bachelor of Science in Tourism Management (BST) and Bachelor of Science in Hospitality Management (BSHM). Admission requires no grades lower than 80 in all subjects, a GWA of 85% or above, and a height requirement of 5'4" for females and 5'6" for males. The official CHTM page is https://www.facebook.com/CHTMOfficial.

The College of Arts and Sciences (CAS) requires a GWA of 90% or above and no grades lower than 85 for the Bachelor of Science in Psychology (preferably HUMSS or STEM strands). The Bachelor of Science in Applied Physics and Bachelor of Science in Mathematics require no grades lower than 80 in all subjects. The official CAS page is https://www.facebook.com/amazingcas.

The College of Education (CED) offers the Bachelor of Secondary Education (BSE) with majors in Filipino, Mathematics, and Science; the Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (BTLEd) with majors in Home Technology and Industrial Arts; and the Bachelor of Special Needs Education (BSNed). The universal qualification for CED is no grades lower than 80 in all subjects. The official CED page is https://www.facebook.com/EARIST.CED.Official.
source: EARIST Admission Posters A.Y. 2025-2026 & Social Media Directory
topic: Requirements for Business, Arts, Education, Criminology, and Hospitality (CBPA, CAS, CED, CCJE, CHTM)

content:
Under the Library Services organizational structure defined in the EARIST Student Handbook, the administration and operation of the library are governed by specific committees and functional groups. The Library Board Committee is headed by a Chairman appointed by the President of the institution. The Director of the Library serves as the secretary of the committee and disseminates information on the activities done by the committee. The members of the committee are composed of the Deans of different colleges, the Director of Instruction, and a student representative from the student government.

The Library Committee serves as the Technical Working Group (TWG) in charge of the review and revision of the Library Manual. It performs monitoring and coordinating tasks to ensure smooth operation and efficient delivery of service by the Institute Library. These functions include reviewing the status of library holdings for the purpose of selecting materials, disseminating information pertaining to policies and operations of the library, participating in the Annual Library Budget Preparation, keeping abreast with recent innovations and developments in instruction, and initiating resource-sharing activities or projects to meet the needs of the library.

In addition to the committee, the Handbook outlines the distinct functions of Professional Librarians and Paraprofessional Librarians. Professional Librarians are responsible for selection and acquisition for collection development, cataloging and classification, provision of bibliographic tools and indexes, and updating current awareness services. They handle information dissemination activities for notices, announcements, and latest news through bulletin boards, signage, newsletters, and media boards. Furthermore, Professional Librarians handle accreditation requirements by preparing needed documents for each program under evaluation, and they manage clearance requirements by signing clearances for student records, enrollment, faculty leaves, transfers, resignations, or retirements. They also facilitate referrals and accommodate endorsements both coming in and going out of the libraries.

Paraprofessional Librarians, acting as support staff, manage circulation works to facilitate use and access to the collection. They provide reading guidance to assist users with proper materials and locations. Their preservation activities include repairing and mending materials for longer use. They handle the mechanical and technical preparation of library materials, including accessioning, labeling, catalog cards, and book card production. Paraprofessional staff also prepare documents for physical inventory, maintain the strictest implementation of rules and regulations for discipline and order, and assist with accreditation and clearance requirements similar to professional staff.
category: Library Services - Organization and General Functions
topic: Library Committee Governance and General Librarian Responsibilities

content:
Under the Library Services section of the EARIST Student Handbook, specific roles and responsibilities are mandated for library staff to ensure efficient performance of tasks. The Director of Library Services maintains an adequate collection that supports the objectives and programs of the school, submits annual program budget proposals and annual reports, supervises library personnel in proper record maintenance and management, evaluates staff job performance, and leads the staff in inventory, cataloging, and classifying books. The Director takes full responsibility for determining policies and procedures in the selection of books in coordination with the library committee and participates in professional organizations.

The Chief of Operations or Assistant Chief of Library Services oversees the technical, operational, and administrative activities of the library. This role involves implementing policies on library use, acquiring reading materials for students and faculty, organizing materials for maximum use, attending seminars for professional growth, conducting book inventory at the end of the school year, developing good reading habits among students, and working cooperatively with academic and administrative staff.

The College Librarian is responsible for selecting, developing, cataloging, and classifying library resources. They answer library users queries, ensure services meet the needs of specific user groups, assist readers with computer equipment and literature searches, promote library resources, maintain proper decorum inside the library, and perform other duties assigned by the library head.

Support Staff members are responsible for the overall operations of service desks depending on their assignments. They maintain statistical records such as client usage frequencies, update information files, perform annual physical inventories, encode library documents, shelf-read books, and maintain the preservation and upkeep of library materials.

Student Assistants and OJT Trainees are tasked with updating shelf-list cards and bibliographic records, repairing slightly mutilated materials, maintaining cleanliness and orderliness, assisting inquiries, helping users with access tools, retrieving books, and maintaining the book collection in all sections.

Finally, Library Coordinators are faculty or personnel designated via Special Order (S.O.) to serve as coordinators for each program. These designations run for a certain period until superseded by another appointment issued by the Office of the President.
topic: Specific Job Descriptions of Library Staff and Officers

content:
Under the Library Services guidelines regarding the Library Collection, materials are categorized into specific types and organized using standardized systems. The collection includes General Reference Books (encyclopedias, dictionaries, almanacs, atlases, handbooks) which are for room use only. Circulation Books cover broad subjects such as Philosophy, Religion, Social Sciences, Language, Arts, Pure Science, Applied Science, Literature, History, and Geography. Periodicals consist of local and foreign journals, magazines, newspapers, government publications, and vertical files like pamphlets; these are strictly for room use. Electronic Resources include e-books, e-journals, online databases, and digital formats like PDF or HTML accessible via hardware or the internet.

The library organizes its holdings according to the Dewey Decimal Classification (DDC) System, which divides knowledge into ten major classes: 000 (General works/Computer Science), 100 (Philosophy/Psychology), 200 (Religion), 300 (Social Sciences), 400 (Language), 500 (Pure Science), 600 (Technology), 700 (Arts & Recreation), 800 (Literature), and 900 (History & Geography). Under this system, books with the same call number are classified as the same subject.

The library operates on an open-shelf system where materials are arranged by section. Books are labeled with place marks or location symbols on top of the call number to indicate their section. For example, the General Circulation collection uses the 'C' symbol. Undergraduate and graduate theses are labeled by their respective courses. To assist users in locating materials, the Union Card Catalog serves as an alphabetical index. It utilizes an Author Card, Title Card, and Subject Card for each book, interfiled following a word-by-word alphabetical arrangement.
topic: Types of Materials, Classification Systems, and Cataloging

content:
According to the Library Sections and Locations guide in the Student Handbook, the library is distributed across multiple floors with specific functions for each area. 

The Ground Floor houses the Museum, which contains memorabilia and vital documents pertaining to 'Amang' and his contributions to EARIST. 

The Second Floor contains the General Collection/Circulation Section, comprising the bulk of materials for undergraduate general education courses (psychology, economics, arts, etc.). The Filipiniana Section is also located on the second floor within the circulation area, housing publications by Filipino authors or foreign authors writing about the Philippines. The Technical Section, responsible for processing and labeling books, operates on both the second and third floors.

The Third Floor houses the General Reference Section, containing encyclopedias, dictionaries, and yearbooks intended for specific information retrieval rather than continuous reading. The Periodical Section is joined with the Graduate School Section on this floor. It provides current and past newspapers, journals, and magazines. The Graduate School Section caters to graduate students and faculty immersed in research, housing theses and dissertations which are strictly for room use and cannot be reproduced. 

The Fourth Floor contains the EARIST Learning Commons (formerly the ICT Room). This section provides access to internet browsing for research work and offers an environment for open communication and collaboration. 

Additionally, the library defines specific 'Readers Services' roles for these sections: The Reference Section assists researchers in book choice; the Filipiniana Section handles local history and culture materials; and the Circulation Section manages the charging and discharging of books.
topic: Library Sections, Locations, and Floor Plan

content:
The EARIST Library Collection Development Policy outlines the objectives and processes for selecting and acquiring library materials. The primary objective is to assist clientele in academic development by providing updated resources that support instruction, research, and extension programs. Selection is a collaborative responsibility involving Deans, faculty, library staff, and students. Faculty recommendations form the basis for acquisitions, while library staff ensure a balanced collection by covering areas not included in recommendations.

Acquisition guidelines prioritize knowledge of the book trade, wide selection, and proper recording. Limitations on acquisition include prioritizing current publications of scholarly value over older materials. Duplicate copies are purchased only upon justification of heavy and continuous use. Variant editions are acquired only if they are standard editions or contain substantial changes needed for research. Hardbound books are preferred over paperbacks for durability, with paperbacks purchased only if no other edition exists or demand is high.

The library maintains specific policies for different material types. For Serials, the library acquires holdings in major fields, public affairs, and research values within financial capabilities. For Filipiniana, the library acquires materials published in or about the Philippines, including government agency publications and university research. The library also engages in Exchanges with other institutions to augment resources.

The policy for Examination Copies dictates that book dealers send materials for inspection. These are reviewed by Deans, Department Chairs, and Library Committee Representatives, who are given one to two weeks to recommend books for purchase.
topic: Collection Development Policy and Acquisition Guidelines

content:
The Student Handbook details the Cataloging and Classification procedures used to organize library materials. A catalog main entry is created for every document, containing class numbers and subject headings. Adequate added entries (author, title, series, editor) are provided to create multiple access points for users. The library utilizes the Anglo-American Cataloging Rules (AACR2) and the Dewey Decimal Classification (DDC) system. Tools used in this process include the Sears List of Subject Headings, DDC, Cutters Table, and AACR2.

The procedure for cataloging books involves classifying the book, identifying the entry point, providing a process slip, encoding the slip for student use, and providing access codes. The purpose of these records is to allow clientele to find information via author, title, subject, series, or illustrator. 

To modernize access, the library employs an Online Public Access Catalog (OPAC). This system is supported by Koha, an open-source, web-based integrated library system used for circulation, cataloging, acquisition, serials, patron management, and reporting. The Technical Section is responsible for the mechanical preparation of materials, including classifying, cataloging, and labeling before items are circulated.
topic: Cataloging, Classification Procedures, and Library Systems

content:
The EARIST Library enforces specific procedures for the maintenance and weeding of its collection to ensure materials remain relevant and in good condition. 

For physical maintenance, the degree of damage determines whether a book is mended, rebound, or replaced. Simple mending is applied to torn pages, while re-binding is considered for worn books with important, unobtainable content. If binding or mending is not feasible, the library adopts weeding procedures for textbooks without permanent value, books beyond repair, and out-of-date reference books.

Weeding is defined as the process of removing unneeded materials to keep the collection fresh and responsive. While factors such as the 'sanctity' of the collection or professional work pressure may discourage weeding, the library mandates it due to space limitations and storage costs. 

The criteria for weeding are based on four main factors: 
1. **Last Date of Circulation:** Items not used in ten years (or less depending on type) are candidates for weeding. 
2. **Physical Condition:** Items in bad condition are weeded unless a decision is made to repair or replace them. 
3. **Timeliness:** This includes out-of-date materials (especially in science and technology, where the rule of thumb is 3-5 years), obsolete textbooks, and materials that no longer support the curriculum. 
4. **Reliability and Language:** Materials reflecting outdated viewpoints or in foreign languages that are no longer taught or used by the community are discarded. Translations should be checked periodically.
topic: Binding, Mending, and Weeding Procedures

content:
According to the institutional records regarding the EARIST Library History, the facility began as the 'Amang' Foundation Library with a limited collection of books and 'Amang' Memorabilia. It originally occupied a room on the third floor of the Apilado Building under the supervision of Ms. Corazon P. Villafania. In 1986, the library transferred to a larger space on the second floor of the Regala Building to accommodate the growing student population, serving as the central library supervised by Chief Librarian Dr. Flocerfida M. Doa and Ms. Erlinda P. Natal. In 2002, per the directive of President Dr. Maura V. Bautista, the central library was devolved to different colleges to align with the vertical structure policy.

Following AACCUP recommendations and accreditation visits, a four-story building was constructed in 2006. The ground floor houses the EARIST Museum. From 2015 to the present, the second floor functions as the General Circulation and Filipiniana Section Library, while the third floor accommodates the Graduate School, Periodicals Section, and Theses Section. The fourth floor serves as the Information Technology Center (ITC), Audio Visual or Multimedia Center, and Learning Commons. The institute remains committed to developing the library to meet modern standards.

The Library Vision envisions the facility as a resource center of quality information serving stakeholders in the pursuit of academic excellence. The Library Mission is to provide services and materials that are accessible, significant, and appropriate for library users. The stated Objectives of the library are to support the institute's program in instructional research and information needs, provide adequate information resources and facilities to the EARIST academic community to achieve school goals, and to develop, enrich, and maintain the library collection to meet the needs of the school's curriculum and programs.
topic: History, Vision, Mission, and Objectives of the EARIST Library

content:
The EARIST Library offers a specific suite of services and operates under defined hours. Library Online Services Hours are from Monday to Thursday, 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM, with no online services available on Saturdays, Sundays, holidays, or school breaks.

The core Library Services include the Circulation Service, which handles the checking out and returning of materials, and the Reference and Information Service, where librarians assist with book choices to encourage effective time use. The Referral Service assists enrolled students, faculty, and staff who wish to use other libraries and accommodates referrals from external institutions. The Computer and Internet Access Service provides computers or laptops for internet access. Library Orientation is conducted weeks after classes start to introduce services and facilities. The Current Awareness Service disseminates the latest information on acquisitions and activities via bulletin boards, newsletters, and the website.

Additional Online Reference and Research Support Services are available via Facebook Messenger, Email, Phone calls, and the website. Document Delivery Services allow for document request pick-up either personally, through a representative, or via courier. A Drop Box for Book Returns is available, requiring the completion of a Google Form, use of the designated box, and an acknowledgment email for confirmation. Remote Access for e-resources is available for both on-site and off-site usage. Online Library Instruction is also provided.

Regarding the Reservation for Use of Equipment and Facilities, requests to reserve the library or equipment for research must be made at least three days in advance to avoid conflicts. The Faculty in charge must inform the librarian and submit a letter of request. The library can be contacted via telephone at 8243-9466 to 68 loc. 122 or email at library@earist.ph.education. The main campus is located at Nagtahan St, Sampaloc, Manila.
topic: Comprehensive List of Physical and Online Library Services

content:
The EARIST Library enforces strict General Rules and Regulations to maintain order and security. Authorized Users include enrolled EARIST students, faculty members, administrators, and staff. Incoming users, visitors, or alumni are also authorized provided they present a referral letter from their respective library and a valid ID.

Under the General Rules, a student must possess a validated school ID to enter. To borrow materials, a student must possess an original Certificate of Registration (COR) valid for the current year. The COR is non-transferable; any misrepresentation or passing of the COR to another student makes the owner liable, and borrowing must be done personally. Bags must be surrendered at the baggage counter, though valuable items like cellphones and wallets should be exempted and kept with the owner.

Behavioral protocols dictate that silence must be observed; idle conversations, loud laughter, and unnecessary noise are prohibited. Students are not allowed to eat, sleep, litter, or loiter inside the library. Library facilities must be kept in order, and chairs must be pushed back before leaving. Charging of laptops, cell phones, and other gadgets is strictly prohibited inside the library.

Regarding the handling of materials, leaning or writing on books is prohibited. Students must refrain from hiding or stealing books. Tearing out pages or forging signatures will result in disciplinary actions. Misbehavior risks the suspension of library privileges or suspension from the library at the librarian's discretion, with repeated cases reported to the discipline officer.

Access for Graduate and undergraduate students and researchers from other schools is limited to room-use only on Fridays, with a maximum of three students per school, upon presentation of a valid ID and referral letter. EARIST Alumni may use the library upon presentation of a valid Alumni ID.
topic: General Rules, Authorized Users, and Behavioral Regulations

content:
The EARIST Library Circulation Policy defines the procedures for borrowing, loan limits, and penalties for infractions. To borrow books, a student must present a valid Certificate of Registration (COR). Students may refer to the card catalog or OPAC for titles or request librarian assistance.

Loan privileges vary by user type. Students are allowed to borrow a maximum of two (2) books for overnight use only. Books for overnight or weekend use may be borrowed one hour before closing time and must be returned on or before 10:00 AM the following service day. Staff and full-time faculty may borrow a maximum of five (5) books every semester, while part-time faculty may borrow a maximum of three (3) books every semester, provided they present valid identification cards. Faculty loans may extend until the end of the semester.

The Loan Period varies by material type. Filipiniana books and general collection books are for overnight use only (Monday to Friday). Fiction books can be borrowed for one week. General references, newspapers, magazines, journals, clippings, theses, and dissertations are strictly for room use only. Reproduction of theses and dissertations in whole or in part is prohibited.

Regarding Penalties, failure to return borrowed books results in the confiscation of the valid COR for a period of 3 days to 1 week (excluding weekends and class suspensions due to inclement weather). The librarian reserves the discretion to suspend library privileges for habitual offenders. For Lost and Damaged Materials, a lost book must be reported immediately to avoid sanctions. Lost books must be replaced with the latest edition of the same title; if unavailable, a related title of the latest edition is acceptable.
topic: Borrowing Procedures, Loan Periods, and Penalties

content:
According to the official Uniform Price List provided by the institution, the pricing structure for student uniforms is categorized by typeInstitutional Male, Institutional Female, and Physical Education (P.E.)and further broken down by specific size ranges. 

For the **Male Institutional Uniform**, the pricing is as follows: The cost for Small and Medium sizes is set at 1,050.00. For students requiring Large or Extra Large (XL) sizes, the price increases to 1,100.00. The larger sizes of 2XL and 3XL are priced at 1,150.00, while the largest available sizes, 4XL and 5XL, are sold for 1,200.00.

The **Female Institutional Uniform** follows a slightly different pricing tier. For female students, the Small and Medium sizes are available at a cost of 950.00. The Large and XL sizes are priced at 1,000.00. For those requiring 2XL or 3XL sizes, the cost is 1,050.00, and the largest sizes of 4XL and 5XL are priced at 1,150.00.

Regarding the **P.E. Uniform**, which is applicable to students across the board, the price list designates the following costs based on size: Small and Medium P.E. uniforms are priced at 900.00. The Large and XL sizes cost 950.00. For 2XL and 3XL sizes, the price is 1,000.00. The 4XL and 5XL sizes are available for 1,050.00. Additionally, the P.E. uniform offers extended sizing options, with 6XL and 7XL sizes available for 1,100.00.
topic: Complete Price List for Institutional and P.E. Uniforms

content:
The official uniform guidelines for the Eulogio 'Amang' Rodriguez Institute of Science & Technology (EARIST) mandate specific components for the Institutional Uniform, differentiated by gender. 

For the **Male Institutional Uniform**, the attire consists of a Maroon Short Sleeves Polo as the upper garment, paired with Beige Slacks as the lower garment. To ensure proper institutional identification, the uniform must include the Earist Logo Pin and the Earist Logo Patch. Furthermore, male students are required to wear the official College I.D. Lace and display their I.D. Card at all times.

For the **Female Institutional Uniform**, the requirements feature an inverted color scheme regarding the garments. Female students must wear a Beige Short Sleeves Blouse as the upper garment, paired with Maroon Slacks. Similar to the male requirements, the female uniform includes mandatory accessories: the Earist Logo Pin and the Earist Logo Patch. The standard requirement for student identification also applies, necessitating the use of the College I.D. Lace and the I.D. Card.

In summary, while both uniforms share the same mandatory accessories (Logo Pin, Logo Patch, I.D. Lace, and I.D. Card), the clothing components differ significantly in color and cut: males wear a maroon top with beige bottoms, whereas females wear a beige top with maroon bottoms.
topic: Detailed Composition of Male and Female Institutional Uniforms

content:
Amang Bot (AmBOT) is the official thesis project developed by 4th-year BSCS students at EARIST to fulfill the study: 'Amang Bot (AmBOT): Utilizing Bidirectional & Autoregressive Transformer with Retrieval-Based Augmentation for EARIST Admissions and Academic Queries.'

**The Origins:**
The foundational concept of Ambot was formulated during a Discord call between Aeron, Orven, and special contributor **John Kyle M. Panta**, who is credited with helping spark the idea.

**The Roster (Team Lore):**
The development team consists of distinct personalities known for specific traits within the group:
* **Aeron Jay Bulatao (Leader & Programmer):** Recognized as the 'GOD' and 'Cobra' of the group.
* **John Luis Labasan (AKA Exit):** The 'Sundalo' who resides in the CAMP AGUINALDO. He is the designated host, as the owner of the house where the team constantly hangs out (tambayan).
* **Christian Jay Baltazar:** Revered as the 'EABAB GODS,' the 'Hustler,' and simply known as 'Master.'
* **John Lester B. Navarro:** Known by the alias 'BADING' and the title 'Pinaka Kupal', though he balances this by being a devoted church-goer.
* **Kenneth Orven T. Asuncion:** The 'ML Gods' (Mobile Legends) Pro Player and the designated 'LRT Buddy.'

**Group History:**
A key piece of history involves Kenneth Orven Asuncion's entry into the group. He was not originally a member but sought a transfer due to a conflict with a former groupmate named Trixia. The transfer was successfully negotiated by buying **Mr. Al** a milk tea.

**Contact & Supervision:**
The project was supervised by Thesis Adviser **Mr. Jovel Advincula** (MIS Office, 4th Floor CCS Building). For inquiries, contact the group leader at bulataoaeronjay@gmail.com.
topic: Origins, Member 'Lore', and Development History

content:
According to the Student Admission, Promotions, & Records Management Services (SARMS) Manual, the Office of the Registrar serves as the primary repository for all student records and acts as the main frontline service for curricular and academic matters. The SARMS mission is to provide academic and administrative support to instruction to enable the attainment of its educational mandate. Its vision is to become a completely automated office providing online services to its clientele. The SARMS commitment is characterized by being service-oriented, efficient, effective, clientele-friendly, honest, trustworthy, and possessing integrity.

The specific objectives of SARMS include selective admission, selective retention of students, efficient and effective management of student records, and providing Total Quality Service. The general functions of the office encompass student admission, registration, promotion and evaluation of student records, records management, curricular information dissemination, and graduation management.

 regarding governance, the President is the head of the Institute, with the Office of the Registrar under their direct supervision in coordination with the Vice-President for Academic Affairs and the Vice-President for Administration & Finance. The College Registrar (Registrar IV) serves as the head of the office and is designated as the Director of Admissions, Registrations, Promotions & Records Management Service. The Registrar is a member of both the Academic Council and the Administrative Council. Personnel under the Registrar include Academic and Non-Academic positions such as Registrar III, Registrar I, Instructors (I-III), Clerks (I-III), and utility workers.
source: Proposed Office of the Registrar Manual
topic: SARMS Mission, Vision, Objectives, and Governance

content:
The Proposed Office of the Registrar Manual outlines the specific functions and responsibilities of the College Registrar. The College Registrar assists top administration in formulating and enforcing policies regarding admissions, enrollment, accreditation, graduation, and related academic matters. The Registrar plans and supervises the admission and selective retention of students, compliance with academic requirements, and the registration process. This role involves enforcing government regulations on scholarships, transferees, accreditation, student loading, subject sequence, cross-enrollment, and graduation honors.

The Registrar evaluates scholastic records for accreditation of transfer units and determines curricular levels and scholastic standing. They are responsible for the custody, security, integrity, and confidentiality of student records, as well as the management and issuance of academic records. Additional duties include disseminating information on curricular offerings and CHED issuances, orienting students on academic policies, and preparing statistical data on enrollment and graduates. The Registrar oversees the publication of the Academic Calendar and Bulletins, signs Transcripts of Records, resolves questions on academic policies, performs curricular consultations, and assists in revising the EARIST Code and Student Handbook.

Administratively, the Registrar maintains linkages with other Registrars, sets standard operating procedures, designs process flow charts, evaluates SARMS personnel performance, manages office property, and creates development plans. The Registrar also submits Annual Accomplishment Reports to the President, acts as Secretary of the Academic Council when designated, and serves as the primary contact person with CHED and the Bureau of Immigration.
source: Proposed Office of the Registrar Manual
topic: Functions and Responsibilities of the College Registrar

content:
The SARMS Manual defines the specific duties for personnel In-charge of Admissions and personnel In-charge of Records/Evaluation (College). 

The In-charge of Admissions prepares admission and enrollment paraphernalia, coordinates the enrollment of new students, and verifies the authenticity of submitted credentials. This role involves requesting Form 137A and the Official Transcript of Records (TOR) for newly admitted students, arranging and filing credentials before turnover to the records section, and serving as the liaison officer for foreign students. They are also responsible for preparing freshmen enrollment lists and statistics regarding transferees.

The In-charge of Records/Evaluation (College) is responsible for preparing individual student records, such as worksheets of consolidated grades, permanent records, and evaluation records. They coordinate student enrollment, post grades, update records regularly, and reconstruct lost files. A critical function of this role is advising students on curricular programs, subject loads, and sequences, as well as informing students of course deficiencies. They evaluate student records regarding curricular level, scholastic standing, and graduation eligibility, including the evaluation of credits earned in other schools. Furthermore, they assist in graduation activities, prepare lists of academic scholars and candidates for graduation (including honors), prepare statistical data for drop-outs and shifters, verify Transcripts of Records, and manage the follow-up of records from previous institutions while ensuring the integrity and confidentiality of all student files.
source: Proposed Office of the Registrar Manual
topic: Roles of Admissions and College Records Personnel

content:
The SARMS Manual details the responsibilities for the In-charge of Secondary Records, the In-charge of Requests/Receiving/Releasing, and the In-charge of Data Processing.

The In-charge of Records (Secondary & Post-Secondary Special Courses) prepares and issues Form 137A and certifications for secondary students. They check entries on Form 138 and Form 18 at the end of the school year, assist in Secondary-Laboratory School graduation activities, and prepare enrollment lists and candidate lists for graduation. They are also responsible for the selection of honor students and the maintenance of all past and present secondary records.

The In-charge of Request, Receiving, and Releasing accommodates and processes requests for Transcripts of Records, certifications, and transfer credentials. This role requires maintaining logbooks for incoming and outgoing records, ensuring prompt compliance with requests, and classifying and storing active and inactive files to secure their integrity.

The In-charge of Data Processing is tasked with encoding data on course and subject codes, new student data, and student grades. They generate worksheets of consolidated grades, Transcripts of Records, certifications, and enrollment lists. This role assists in accomplishing survey forms and prepares all needed statistical data while ensuring the security and confidentiality of digital student records.
source: Proposed Office of the Registrar Manual
topic: Secondary Records, Requests, and Data Processing Roles

content:
According to the Office Management section of the SARMS Manual, the Office of the Registrar is physically located at the Student Center, specifically in the left wing of the Apilado Hall, fronting Nagtahan Street. The office occupies both the ground floor and the mezzanine. The ground floor houses the Request/Receiving/Releasing Section, the Evaluation Section for all colleges, the ID Section, and the Records Room for both graduated and active/inactive files. The mezzanine accommodates the SARMS Director/College Registrar's office, the Mini-SARMS Library/Research Room, the Data Processing Section, and the stockroom for supplies.

The manual mandates specific office layout standards: the working area must be spacious enough for employees, and service counters must be adequate to handle students from different colleges. Distinct rooms must be provided for inactive files, graduated files, and computers. Active files are required to be located in the immediate vicinity of the Evaluators. Furthermore, the office must maintain sufficient furniture, lighting, and ventilation. A 1:1 computer-to-personnel ratio is required, separate from servers used for data banking.

Regarding File Arrangements, the manual classifies records into three categories with specific storage protocols. Active Files are arranged by College and alphabetized, located in the immediate vicinity of the concerned College In-charge. Inactive Files are alphabetized and stored on the Ground Floor. Graduated Files are alphabetized by College and by Year, also stored on the Ground Floor.
source: Proposed Office of the Registrar Manual
topic: Office Location, Layout, and File Arrangement Standards

content:
The SARMS Manual outlines strict guidelines for Personnel Assignments and Manpower. A key operational standard is that the number of employees must be proportional to the student population, with a maximum ratio of one (1) personnel for every 500 students (1:500). Every staff member must have definite duties and responsibilities.

Specific personnel assignments are designated by role and college jurisdiction. The Registrar IV acts as the Director located on the mezzanine. The Registrar III serves as the Assistant Registrar In-charge of the Graduate School. The Evaluation and Promotions Section is led by a Registrar I. Specific Instructors and Clerks are detailed as Chiefs of sections such as Records, Documentation & Authentication, and Data Processing.

College-specific records are managed by designated officers: The College of Engineering (BSCE, ECE, BSME, BSEE) is managed by the Chief of Records Section. The College of Industrial Technology (BSIT) is managed by an Instructor II. The College of Arts & Sciences is managed by the Chief of Documentation. The College of Business & Public Administration and Industrial Technology (BSHRM) are managed by a Clerk III. The College of Architecture and Engineering (BSCOE) fall under the Chief of Admission & Registration. Secondary Records (LHS) and the College of Education are managed by the Chief of Data Processing.

To address future needs, the manual proposes the creation of additional positions: Registrar V (University Registrar), Registrar II (Admission, Recruitment & Testing Officer), Credit Evaluator (Academic Rank Holder), Computer Programmer, Data Encoder, Computer-literate Records Clerk, and Regular Student Assistants.
source: Proposed Office of the Registrar Manual
topic: Personnel Assignments, Ratios, and Proposed Manpower

content:
The SARMS Manual establishes Operating Procedures regarding attendance, communications, and the safety of records. Personnel are required to be punctual, and office hours must be clearly posted for the public. Staff may be required to render honorarium services after regular hours to accommodate evening and working students. 

Communication protocols dictate that the In-charge of Admission is responsible for receiving, sorting, and recording all incoming credentials and communications. Outgoing communications must be recorded with the name of the document, the recipient College/Office, the date, and the receiver's signature. Specific personnel are assigned to handle correspondence regarding curricular offerings and statistical data.

Security and Safety standards are strictly enforced. Classified or confidential records (e.g., student academic records) cannot be accessed by unauthorized persons or taken out of the office. Unclassified records may only be borrowed with the Director's permission, provided the transaction is logged with the borrower's details. The storeroom and Computer Room are restricted areas. Only authorized personnel or Data Processing staff may access student records on computers. The manual recommends microfilming records for maximum security.

Facilities maintenance requires that working areas and record rooms be free from fire hazards. Files must be treated with insecticides/pesticides occasionally. Record rooms must be temperature-controlled to preserve documents and equipment. Malfunctioning equipment must be reported immediately, and economy in the use of supplies is mandated.
source: Proposed Office of the Registrar Manual
topic: Operating Procedures, Communication Protocols, and Records Security

content:
According to the Files and Records Management section of the SARMS Manual, records at the Office of the Registrar are categorized into two distinct classifications: Strictly Confidential and Unclassified/Non-confidential.

Strictly Confidential records refer to documents submitted pursuant to the school's special relationship with the student, intended solely for admission or promotion purposes. These include Academic reports, Adoption papers, Alien Certificate of Registration, Baptismal or Birth Certificates, Disciplinary Records, Medical and Guidance Reports, and Personal and Academic Records.

Unclassified or Non-confidential records are those that must be made public to enable the State, students, and parents to assess the school's performance and legal existence. These include Course Approvals, Catalogues, Class/Faculty/Room Programs, Directory of Graduates, Enrollment Lists, Permits and Recognition, Prospectus, School Annuals, Statistical records, and Teaching Contracts.

The manual also specifies the required credentials to be filed in the individual Student Jacket. These documents include the Accreditation/Validation Form, Adding/Changing/Dropping Form, Admission Slip, Affidavits for name changes, and Applications for admission, graduation, shifting, or transfer. Furthermore, the jacket must contain approved permits for cross-enrollment, OJT, overload, subject substitution, and waivers. Essential academic records such as the Certificate of Transfer Credentials, Clearance/Completion forms, Schedule/Registration Forms, Form 138, Form 137-A, and Transcript of Records (TOR) must be included. Finally, machine copies of the ACR, Birth Certificate, and Marriage Contract, along with Notices of Deficiency, Permanent Records, photographs, and study permits for working/foreign students are mandatory inclusions.
source: Proposed Office of the Registrar Manual
topic: Classification of Records and Student Jacket Contents

content:
The SARMS Manual outlines the maintenance of "Sundry Matters" or reference files and establishes specific Operating Procedures for filing systems and record control. 

Reference files retained by the office include Annual/Monthly Accomplishment Reports, Annual Procurement Programs, Checklists/Prospectuses, Class/Faculty/Room Programs, and Commencement Programs. The office also maintains copies of CHED Basic Higher Education Data, CHED Memos/Orders, Civil Service Circulars, CSC PD 907, DBM Memo No. 71 (Head Count), and DBM/SUC Form 1A. Regarding student data, the office keeps Enrollment lists, Worksheets for Consolidated Grades, Grade Sheets, Lists of Academic Scholars, and Lists of Candidates for Graduation with honors. Governance documents such as Minutes of Academic Council Meetings, Official Communications, SARMS Memoranda, EARIST Circulars/Orders, the EARIST Code, Faculty Manual, and Student Handbook are also archived.

The Operating Procedure for file location dictates that Active/Current files must be stored in a separate cabinet in the immediate vicinity of the concerned College Evaluators. In-active (dropped) files and Graduated Files are located in the SARMS Ground Floor records room.

The Filing System and Control of Records mandates the use of an alphabetic file for students' permanent records to prevent displacement. Student records are kept in individual jackets, and great care must be taken to ensure papers are filed immediately upon receipt into the correct jacket. For digital records, the Student Number is used for encoding and accessing data in the computer system, managed by designated data processing personnel. Sundry matters are filed by subject and further classified by year or school year.
source: Proposed Office of the Registrar Manual
topic: Reference Files (Sundry Matters) and Operating Procedures

content:
The General Workflow at the Office of the Registrar follows a structured process spanning Pre-Registration to Data Encoding.

The Pre-Registration phase involves the preparation and issuance of pre-enrollment forms and admission slips indicating deficiencies for old students. It includes the administration of the College Admission Test (ECAT) in coordination with the SSC, the analysis and dissemination of ECAT results to Deans, and the coordination of integrated school programs. This phase also covers the dissemination of the school calendar and enrollment procedures.

The Admission and Registration phases cover the processing of both old and new students. Following Registration is the Post-Registration phase, which involves sorting registration forms by College, Course, Major, Level, and Sex. This step leads to the preparation of Enrollment Lists and Statistics, and the creation of jackets for new student records.

The workflow continues with Filing, Sorting, and Arrangement, where entrance credentials and registration forms are filed into student jackets, and files for dropped or transferred students are sorted. The Student Records Preparation phase involves requesting Form 137-A for freshmen and Transcripts for transferees, encoding personal data, and recording currently enrolled subjects. Finally, the Posting and Encoding phase entails posting grades from grade sheets to permanent records and updating the computerized consolidated worksheets.
source: Proposed Office of the Registrar Manual
topic: Workflow: Pre-Registration, Admission, Registration, and Encoding

content:
The SARMS Manual details the workflow for Student Evaluation, Graduation, and the Issuance of Academic Records. 

The Evaluation phase focuses on reviewing student records for promotion to the next curriculum year. This involves identifying and disseminating information regarding student deficiencies and earned credits. Staff must advise students on subject pre-requisites, co-requisites, and mandated subjects. This phase also includes processing applications for graduation, selecting honor students, and preparing the List of Candidates for Graduation.

The Graduation phase formalizes the process. It involves presenting the Candidates for Graduation to the Local College Academic Council and the Institute Academic Council for approval. The list is then prepared for the President's approval and confirmation by the EARIST Board of Trustees. This phase also manages the preparation of PD 907 awardees and the holding of graduation rites.

The final workflow stage is the Preparation and Issuance of Requested Academic Records. This entails accommodating student requests and generating official documents, including Transcripts of Records for graduated and non-graduated students, certifications, and certificates of good moral character.
source: Proposed Office of the Registrar Manual
topic: Workflow: Evaluation, Graduation, and Record Issuance

content:
According to the SARMS Manual, the Admissions Unit is responsible for processing new freshmen, transferees, and foreign students in coordination with the various Colleges. The In-charge of Admissions coordinates the number of students and sections to be opened, processes entrance credentials, and informs students of incomplete requirements. This role specifically includes requesting Form 137-A for freshmen and Official Transcripts of Records (TOR) for transferees from previous institutions. For foreign students, the unit manages admission requirements and submits necessary reports to the Bureau of Immigration.

The manual outlines strict criteria for the Evaluation of Credentials. Documents considered invalid for registration include: transfer cards (F-138) not stating eligibility or unsigned by the Principal/Registrar; documents marked "used for enrollment in another school" or "cancelled"; credentials with alterations or erasures; diplomas (alone); and Transcripts marked "For Evaluation Only" or "For Employment Purposes." Furthermore, credentials from private schools without government permit/recognition are invalid. The manual specifies verification techniques, such as using a magnifying glass or a light source to detect deceptive erasures. 

Regarding the Verification of Authenticity, the In-charge of Records must verify all hand-carried Transcripts of Records. This is achieved by sending a copy to the originating school for authentication or dispatching a SARMS liaison officer. For graduate students or those taking second degrees, Transcripts must contain the degree obtained, graduation date, and CHED Special Order Number (or Registry Order for accredited private schools).
source: Proposed Office of the Registrar Manual
topic: Admissions Procedures, Credential Evaluation, and Authenticity Verification

content:
The SARMS Manual details the Registration and Enrollment protocols. The process is guided by an Enrollment Memorandum and the Academic Calendar. Colleges are responsible for enrolling their students and submitting reports to SARMS. Old students are required to present a complete set of class cards from the previous semester, the previous registration form, and a clearance. Graduating students must be provided with a Notice of Deficiencies.

Specific academic policies govern the enrollment process. Practice Teaching must not be taken with any other subjects to ensure total immersion (citing CMO No. 11, s. 1999). Advanced subjects cannot be enrolled by transferees unless prerequisites are validated. Scholastic delinquent students and academic scholars must adhere to their specific rules and contracts. Late submission of Registration Forms is prohibited unless permitted by the Dean of Student Affairs with necessary sanctions.
