content:
According to the Outcome-Based Teaching and Learning (OBTL) Plan for the Eulogio 'Amang' Rodriguez Institute of Science & Technology (EARIST), the Institute operates under a specific philosophy, mission, and vision. The Institute Philosophy states that education is not an area of knowledge arrogated by one profession, nor is it separate from society. Rather, it is a plexus of knowledge and skills applied to the economic, social, and moral development of a self-actualized and productive citizenry. The Institute Mission is to turn out vocationally, technically, technologically, and scientifically trained graduates who will be economically productive, self-sufficient, effective, responsible, and disciplined citizens of the Philippines. The Institute Vision envisions EARIST as a center of excellence in trades, business, arts, science, and technology education. The Core Values are represented by the acronym EARIST: Excellence, Accountability, Resourcefulness, Integrity, Service, and Teamwork.

Within the College of Arts and Sciences, the Bachelor of Science in Information Technology (BSIT) Department adheres to specific College Goals. These goals are: to develop students' ability to acquire knowledge, think logically, analyze confidently, and express themselves creatively with high moral awareness; to encourage students to realize personal and professional goals through self-motivation and the pursuit of excellence; to foster lifelong competence and interest in research regarding science, technology, economy, and industry; and to provide avenues for student involvement in extension and production programs for professional and community development.
topic: EARIST Philosophy, Mission, Vision, Core Values, and CAS Goals

content:
The Bachelor of Science in Information Technology (BSIT) program at EARIST outlines specific Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO) that graduates must demonstrate. These outcomes are categorized into three sections: common to all programs, common to ITE disciplines, and specific to BSIT.

Outcomes common to all programs require graduates to: (1) articulate the latest developments in their specific field of practice; (2) effectively communicate orally and in writing using English and Filipino; (3) work effectively and independently in multi-disciplinary and multi-cultural teams; (4) demonstrate professional, social, and ethical responsibility, particularly regarding intellectual property and sustainable development; and (5) preserve and promote Filipino historical and cultural heritage.

Outcomes common to ITE disciplines require graduates to: (6) analyze complex problems and identify computing requirements for solutions; (7) apply computing knowledge to address real-world problems; (8) design and develop computing solutions using a system-level perspective; (9) utilize modern computing tools; and (13) possess knowledge and understanding of information security issues.

Outcomes specific to BS Information Technology require graduates to: (10) apply knowledge of computing fundamentals, specialization, mathematics, and science to abstract and conceptualize computing models; (11) identify, analyze, and solve complex computing problems using fundamental principles of mathematics and computing sciences; (12) apply mathematical foundations and algorithmic principles in the modeling and design of computer-based systems, demonstrating comprehension of design tradeoffs; (14) design and evaluate solutions for complex computing problems, ensuring safety and cultural considerations; (15) create, select, and apply appropriate techniques and tools to complex computing activities; (16) function effectively as an individual or leader in diverse teams; (17) communicate effectively with the computing community and society regarding complex activities; (18) recognize legal, social, ethical, and professional issues; (19) engage in independent learning for continual development; and (20) participate in employment and development activities responsive to community needs.
topic: BS Information Technology Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO)

content:
The course ITINTERN (Practicum/Internship) is a 4th-year standing requirement for BSIT students. It carries 1 laboratory credit unit but requires a substantial time commitment. The course prerequisites include 4th Year Standing. The course description mandates that students undergo 450 hours of On-the-Job Training (OJT) and an additional 36 hours for briefing and orientation. The course exposes students to practical work expected of an Information Technology graduate, such as roles including computer programmer, software engineer, system software developer, applications software developer, data analyst, quality assurance specialist, and software support specialist. Training takes place in various industrial and commercial IT companies.

Upon completion of ITINTERN, students are expected to achieve specific Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILO) that align with EARIST Desired Graduate Elements (EDGE). These outcomes include: integrating and applying theory and understanding from Computer Science courses in a work environment; using common techniques and skills of the computer and information technology field; observing and taking part in the management of technology changes within an organization; understanding the industry environment of the internship provider; demonstrating community involvement and reflecting on encountered issues; and demonstrating the ability to work with supervision and other employees while performing tasks to the supervisor's satisfaction. These outcomes map to EDGE attributes such as Problem Analysis, Development of Solutions, Global Citizenship, Collaboration & Communication, Professionalism and Ethics, and Lifelong Learning.
topic: ITINTERN Course Description, Requirements, and Learning Outcomes

content:
The ITINTERN course follows a structured Teaching and Learning Plan spanning 18 weeks. 

Week 1 focuses on Course Orientation and a review of the Institute's VMGO (Vision, Mission, Goals, Objectives). Activities include teacher-led discussions and individual oral recitation regarding the course requirements.

Weeks 2-3 differ based on the student's progress in securing a placement. This period covers the 'Preparation of BSCS Internship Program' (noted as BSCS in text, likely applies to BSIT context) and 'Orientation of the practicum.' Specific topics include the presentation of industrial companies accepting practicumers, orientation on OJT settings and procedures, presentation of roles, and waivers. Students must write application letters and Curriculum Vitae. The required output materials during this phase are the Approved Application Letter, Approved Recommendation Letter, Notarized Memorandum of Agreement, and Narrative Reports.

Weeks 4-17 constitute the 'Actual On-the-Job Training' phase. Students are deployed to different OJT partners. During this time, they must submit a weekly reflective narrative report (Journal) to the instructor. The internship coordinator conducts actual visitation and consultation with students and industry supervisors. Assessments during this period include the Daily Time Record and Narrative Report/Journal.

Week 9 is designated for the Midterm Examination (Summative Examination), and Week 18 is designated for the Final Examination. Throughout the deployment, communication involves online weekly journals and consultations.
topic: Weekly Teaching and Learning Plan for ITINTERN

content:
The grading system for the ITINTERN course assesses students through graded and ungraded activities. The final grade is calculated based on the following weights: Written Work (Homework, Problem Sets, Narrative Reports) accounts for 25%; Performance Tasks (Quizzes, Projects, Research Papers, OJT Performance) account for 45%; and Term Assessment (Midterm/Final Exam) accounts for 30%. The Final Rating is computed as the average of the Midterm Grade (50%) and the Final Grade (50%).

The numerical grading scale used by EARIST is as follows:
- 1.00: 97-100% (Highly Excellent)
- 1.25: 94-96% (Excellent)
- 1.50: 91-93% (Very Superior)
- 1.75: 88-90% (Superior)
- 2.00: 85-87% (Very Good)
- 2.25: 82-84% (Good)
- 2.50: 79-81% (Satisfactory)
- 2.75: 76-78% (Fair)
- 3.00: 75% (Passed)
- 5.00: Below 75% (Failed)

Course policies mandate that the language of instruction is English. Regarding attendance, students are required to attend all classes (or OJT shifts) starting from the first meeting. Accumulating absences totaling more than 20 percent of the scheduled hours will result in being automatically dropped from the class roll. Regarding Academic Integrity, all submitted work must be original; cheating or plagiarism is treated according to the Institute's Policy on Academic Integrity, with penalties ranging from failing the assignment to failing the class. The Institute also supports Learners with Disabilities, requiring students to register with the Office of Student Affairs and Services (OSAS) to establish reasonable accommodations.
topic: Grading System, Rubrics, and Course Policies

content:
According to the Outcome-Based Teaching and Learning (OBTL) Plan for the System Administration and Maintenance course (SYSADMLC), the Eulogio 'Amang' Rodriguez Institute of Science & Technology (EARIST) operates under a defined Philosophy, Mission, and Vision. The Institute Philosophy posits that education is a plexus of knowledge and skills applied to the economic, social, and moral development of a self-actualized and productive citizenry. The Institute Mission is to produce vocationally, technically, technologically, and scientifically trained graduates who are economically productive and responsible citizens. The Institute Vision sees EARIST as a center of excellence in trades, business, arts, science, and technology education. The Core Values are Excellence, Accountability, Resourcefulness, Integrity, Service, and Teamwork.

The College of Arts and Sciences (CAS) has specific goals: to develop students' ability to acquire knowledge, think logically, and express themselves creatively with moral awareness; to encourage personal and professional growth through self-motivation; to foster interest in research regarding science, technology, economy, and industry; and to provide avenues for extension and production programs. The BS Information Technology Program aims to develop graduates who are globally competent, innovative, socially and ethically responsible, and engaged in lifelong learning. Program goals include analyzing complex problems to design appropriate solutions, applying computing knowledge to real-world problems, utilizing modern computing tools, and developing competencies to support national and local development plans.
topic: EARIST Philosophy, Mission, Vision, and CAS Goals

content:
The OBTL Plan for SYSADMLC lists the Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO) for the BS Information Technology program. Graduates are expected to articulate the latest developments in their field, communicate effectively in English and Filipino, work in multi-disciplinary teams, and demonstrate professional and ethical responsibility. Specific technical outcomes include: applying knowledge of computing, science, and mathematics; understanding best practices and standards; analyzing complex problems to identify computing requirements; and identifying user needs for the selection and administration of computer-based systems.

Furthermore, graduates must be able to design, implement, and evaluate systems under various constraints; integrate IT-based solutions into user environments; and analyze the local and global impact of computing. They are expected to recognize the need for continuing professional development and function effectively as team members or leaders. Additional competencies include assisting in the creation of IT project plans and engaging in public discourse to respond to community needs. The outcomes align with CMO No. 46, s. 2012 and RA 7722, ensuring graduates are prepared for employment and national development.
topic: Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO) for BS Information Technology

content:
The course 'SYSADMLC' (System Administration and Maintenance) is a 2-unit lecture course with no prerequisites. The course description indicates that it teaches students to understand the deployment and maintenance of modern computer systems, emphasizing user account administration. It covers basic administrative tasks for network operating systems like Windows and Linux, including the installation and configuration of mainstream operating systems, network services, disaster recovery procedures, and security techniques.

Upon completion, students are expected to achieve specific Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILO) mapped to the EARIST Graduate Elements (EDGE). Students should proficiently learn and apply basic concepts of System Administration and Security by building a miniature corporate network from the ground up. They must understand the installation of backend servers required for daily operations and validate network functionality from a user's perspective. Additionally, students are expected to apply and implement security measures and conduct risk assessments regarding the effectiveness of those measures. These outcomes align with EDGE attributes such as Problem Analysis (PS), Development of Solutions (DoS), and Professionalism and Ethics (PaE).
topic: SYSADMLC Course Description and Learning Outcomes

content:
The teaching plan for the first six weeks of the SYSADMLC course focuses on foundational networking and server administration. Week 1 is dedicated to orientation, discussing the Institute's VMGO, PILOs, CILOs, and course requirements like the syllabus and assessment tools. Week 2 covers the 'Networking Overview', including the history of networking, protocol standards, the OSI Model, TCP/IP, Windows and Linux networks, and basics of switching and routing. Students are expected to explain networking standards and navigate systems using standard tools.

Weeks 3 and 4 focus on 'Server Administrations'. Topics include Server and Client Installation, the Boot Process and Startup Services, Managing Accounts, File Systems, Disk Quota Management, Job Scheduling, Process Controlling, and Online Server upgrade/update processes. Students learn to design plans for installation and manage accounts and file systems. Weeks 5 and 6 cover 'Network Configuration' and 'Static and DHCP'. This includes IPv4 and IPv6 addressing, Network Interface Configuration, diagnosing networks, and firewall configurations for Linux and Windows. It also covers Static Principles versus DHCP, DHCP Server Configuration, Options, Scope, Reservations, Relaying, and troubleshooting. Students apply these concepts to design IP networks and fix network problems.
topic: Weekly Plan: Networking Basics, Server Administration, and Configuration

content:
From Weeks 7 to 13, the curriculum shifts to deploying specific network services. Weeks 7 and 8 focus on 'Name Server and Configuration' (DNS). This includes DNS principles and operations, Basic Name Server and Client Configuration, Caching Only name servers, Primary and Slave name servers, DNS Zone Transfers, Dynamic Updates, Delegation, and DNS Server Security. Students are tasked with designing and configuring DNS services and managing DNS cache.

Week 9 is reserved for the Midterm Examination. Weeks 10 and 11 cover 'Web and Proxy Server Configuration'. Topics include Basic HTTP Server Configuration, Virtual Hosting, HTTP Caching, Proxy Caching Server Configuration, Proxy ACL, Proxy-Authentication Mechanisms, and troubleshooting. Students learn to enable indirect access for security and design load balancing between servers. Weeks 12 and 13 address 'FTP, File and Print Server' administration. This module introduces Samba and its configuration (including SWAT), NFS and NFS Client Configuration, CUPS Configuration, FTP Principles, and Printer Configuration (Local, AppSocket, Samba Printer). The goal is to promote file sharing and configure local network administration settings to ensure connectivity.
topic: Weekly Plan: DNS, Web, Proxy, and File Servers

content:
The final phase of the course, spanning Weeks 14 to 18, covers advanced administration and security implementation. Week 14 focuses on 'Mail Server' technologies, including SMTP, POP, and IMAP principles, SMTP Relaying, Mail Domain Administration, SPAM Control and Filtering, and troubleshooting. Students explain the mail server process and install mail servers. Week 15 covers 'Remote Administration and Management', discussing Router Configuration, Web/User Admin, and tools like TeamViewer, Telnet, and SSH. Students design and deploy roles on remote servers.

Week 16 addresses 'Configuration and Maintenance', which includes System Configuration Policy, Controlling Causes and Symptoms, Change Management, Clock Synchronization, Job Scheduling, and Preventative Host Maintenance. Week 17 focuses on 'Security and Implementation', covering System Design and Normalization, Recovery Plans, Data Integrity, Authentication Methods, Role-based Security, IPSec, IP filtering, Firewalls, and Intrusion Detection/Forensics. The course concludes with the Final Examination in Week 18.
topic: Weekly Plan: Mail Servers, Remote Admin, Maintenance, and Security

content:
The grading system for SYSADMLC comprises Written Work (25%), Performance Tasks (45%), and Term Assessments (30%). The Final Rating is an average of the Midterm Grade (50%) and Final Grade (50%). The numerical grading scale ranges from 1.00 (97-100%, Highly Excellent) to 5.00 (Below 75%, Failed), with a passing grade of 3.00 (75%). 

Course policies mandate English as the language of instruction. Attendance is compulsory; students absent for more than 20% of scheduled hours will be dropped. Academic integrity is strictly enforced, with penalties for cheating or plagiarism ranging from failing the assignment to failing the class. The Institute supports learners with disabilities, who must register with the Office of Student Affairs and Services (OSAS) for accommodations. The syllabus is flexible and subject to change by the instructor with approval. Key textbooks include 'Windows Server 2008: Unleashed' and 'The Complete Reference Microsoft Windows Server 2008'.
topic: Grading System, Course Policies, and Learning Resources

content:
According to the Outcome-Based Teaching and Learning (OBTL) Plan for the Quantitative Methods (Lecture) course (QUAMETLC), the Eulogio 'Amang' Rodriguez Institute of Science & Technology (EARIST) operates under a specific Philosophy, Mission, and Vision. The Institute Philosophy states that education is not an area of knowledge arrogated by one profession, nor is it separate from society. Instead, it is a plexus of knowledge and skills applied to the economic, social, and moral development of a self-actualized and productive citizenry. The Institute Mission is to produce vocationally, technically, technologically, and scientifically trained graduates who are economically productive, self-sufficient, effective, responsible, and disciplined citizens. The Institute Vision envisions EARIST as a center of excellence in trades, business, arts, science, and technology education. The Core Values are Excellence, Accountability, Resourcefulness, Integrity, Service, and Teamwork.

The College of Arts and Sciences (CAS) has specific goals: to develop students' ability to acquire knowledge, think logically, and express themselves creatively with high moral awareness; to encourage students to realize personal and professional goals through self-motivation and the pursuit of excellence; to foster lifelong competence and interest in research regarding science, technology, economy, and industry; and to provide avenues for student involvement in extension and production programs for professional and community development. The BS Information Technology Program aims to become globally competent, innovative, socially and ethically responsible, and engaged in life-long learning endeavors.
topic: EARIST Philosophy, Mission, Vision, Core Values, and CAS Goals

content:
The Bachelor of Science in Information Technology (BSIT) program at EARIST outlines specific Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO) that graduates must demonstrate. These outcomes are categorized into those common to all programs, common to computing disciplines, and specific to BSIT.

Graduates must be able to: (1) articulate the latest developments in their specific field of practice; (2) effectively communicate orally and in writing using both English and Filipino languages; (3) work effectively and independently in multi-disciplinary and multi-cultural teams; (4) demonstrate professional, social, and ethical responsibility, especially in practicing intellectual property rights and sustainable development; and (5) preserve and promote Filipino historical and cultural heritage.

Specific to the Computing Studies Disciplines, graduates must: (10) apply knowledge of computing, science, and mathematics; (11) understand best practices and standards; (12) analyze complex problems and define computing requirements; (13) identify and analyze user needs for system selection and administration; (14) design, implement, and evaluate computer-based systems under various constraints; (15) integrate IT-based solutions into the user environment; (19) communicate effectively with the computing community and society; (20) analyze the logical and global impact of computing; (21) understand professional, ethical, legal, and security issues; (22) engage in independent learning and professional development; and (23) participate in employment and development activities.

Specific to BSIT, graduates must: (6) analyze complex problems and identify requirements for solutions; (7) apply computing knowledge to real-world problems; (8) design and develop solutions using a system-level perspective; (9) utilize modern computing tools; (16) apply current techniques and skills necessary for the IT profession; (17) function effectively as a member or leader of a development team; (18) assist in the creation of effective IT project plans; and (24) develop competencies to support national, regional, and local development plans.
topic: BS Information Technology Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO)

content:
The course QUAMETLC (Quantitative Methods - Lecture) is a 2-unit course requiring 2 lecture hours per week. The prerequisite for this course is MMDIALEC. The course description states that it applies to learning quantitative data and quantitative analysis, demonstrating the processes involved in data analysis and basic statistical analysis.

Upon completion of QUAMETLC, students are expected to achieve specific Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILO) that align with EARIST Desired Graduate Elements (EDGE). Students should be able to proficiently: understand Quantitative Analysis; analyze Quantitative Data; examine the relationships between and among variables to answer questions and hypotheses through surveys and experiments; create data analysis using tools like Scattergrams; present data in graphical forms such as Line Graphs, Bar Graphs, and Histograms; and create a project study utilizing the stages in the Data Analysis process (Description, Interpretation, Conclusion, and Theorization). These outcomes map to EDGE attributes including Problem Analysis (PS), Development of Solutions (DoS), Global Citizenship (GC), Collaboration & Communication (CaC), Professionalism and Ethics (PaE), and Lifelong Learning (LL).
topic: QUAMETLC Course Description, Requirements, and Learning Outcomes

content:
The Teaching and Learning Plan for QUAMETLC outlines the schedule for the first half of the semester. Week 1 focuses on Orientation, including a discussion of the Institute's VMGO, PILOs, CILOs, and syllabus content. Activities include teacher-led discussions and individual oral recitation regarding course requirements.

Weeks 2-5 cover 'Defining Surveys and Experiments.' This includes Survey Design, Experimental Design, Components of a Survey Study Method Plan, The Population and Sample, and Instrumentation. Students are expected to design quantitative methods with a specific focus on survey and experimental designs, culminating in the creation of a Survey Instrument. Weeks 6-8 focus on 'Variables in Quantitative Analysis.' Topics include Independent Variables, Dependent Variables, Predictor Variables, Outcome Variables, Intervening Variables, and Moderating Variables. The learning outcome is to examine relationships between variables to answer questions and hypotheses. Week 9 is designated for the Midterm Examination (Summative Examination).
topic: Weekly Plan: Orientation, Survey Design, and Variables

content:
The Teaching and Learning Plan for QUAMETLC continues from Week 10 through Week 18, focusing on analysis and presentation. Weeks 10-12 cover 'Data Analysis,' specifically Steps in Data Analysis, Descriptive Analysis, Inferential Analysis, and Scattergrams. Students learn to create data analysis using software tools such as IBM SPSS Statistics, SYSTAT, SAS/STAT, Stata, and MS Excel.

Weeks 13-14 focus on 'Graphing Data,' covering Line Graphs, Bar Graphs, and Histograms. The objective is to present data in graphical form. Weeks 15-17 cover the 'Stages in the Data Analysis Process,' which includes Description, Interpretation, Conclusion, and Theorization. During this phase, students are tasked with creating a project study utilizing these stages. The course concludes with the Final Examination in Week 18. Reference materials for the course include 'Research Methods- Structuring Inquiries and Empirical Investigation' by Cristina Quinlan and 'Research Design' by J.W. Creswell.
topic: Weekly Plan: Data Analysis, Graphing, and Project Study

content:
The grading system for the QUAMETLC course assesses students through graded and ungraded activities. The final grade is calculated based on the following weights: Written Work (Homework, Problem Sets) accounts for 25%; Performance Tasks (Quizzes, Projects, Research Papers) account for 45%; and Term Assessment (Midterm/Final Exam) accounts for 30%. The Final Rating is computed as the average of the Midterm Grade (50%) and the Final Grade (50%).

The numerical grading scale used by EARIST is as follows:
- 1.00: 97-100% (Highly Excellent)
- 1.25: 94-96% (Excellent)
- 1.50: 91-93% (Very Superior)
- 1.75: 88-90% (Superior)
- 2.00: 85-87% (Very Good)
- 2.25: 82-84% (Good)
- 2.50: 79-81% (Satisfactory)
- 2.75: 76-78% (Fair)
- 3.00: 75% (Passed)
- 5.00: Below 75% (Failed)

Course policies mandate that the language of instruction is English. Regarding attendance, students are required to attend all classes starting from the first meeting. Accumulating absences totaling more than 20 percent of the scheduled hours will result in being automatically dropped from the class roll. Regarding Academic Integrity, all submitted work must be original; cheating or plagiarism is treated according to the Institute's Policy on Academic Integrity. The Institute also supports Learners with Disabilities, requiring students to register with the Office of Student Affairs and Services (OSAS) for accommodations.
topic: Grading System, Rubrics, and Course Policies

content:
The Bachelor of Science in Information Technology (BSIT) program outlines specific Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO) that graduates must demonstrate. These are categorized into outcomes common to all programs, common to computing disciplines, and specific to the program.

Graduates must be able to: (1) articulate the latest developments in their specific field of practice; (2) effectively communicate orally and in writing using both English and Filipino; (3) work effectively and independently in multi-disciplinary teams; (4) demonstrate professional, social, and ethical responsibility; and (5) preserve and promote Filipino historical and cultural heritage.

Specific to Computing Studies, graduates must: (10) apply knowledge of computing, science, and mathematics; (11) understand best practices and standards; (12) analyze complex problems and define computing requirements; (13) identify and analyze user needs; (14) design, implement, and evaluate computer-based systems under various constraints; (15) integrate IT-based solutions into the user environment; (19) communicate effectively with the computing community; (20) analyze the logical and global impact of computing; (21) understand professional, ethical, legal, and security issues; (22) engage in independent learning; and (23) participate in employment and development activities.

Specific to BSIT, graduates must: (6) analyze complex problems and identify requirements for solutions; (7) apply computing knowledge to real-world problems; (8) design and develop solutions using a system-level perspective; (9) utilize modern computing tools; (16) apply current techniques and skills necessary for the IT profession; (17) function effectively as a member or leader of a development team; (18) assist in the creation of effective IT project plans; and (24) develop competencies to support national, regional, and local development plans.
topic: BS Information Technology Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO)

content:
The course ITTHESL2 (Thesis 2 - Laboratory) is a 1-unit laboratory course requiring 3 contact hours per week. The prerequisite for this course is ITTHESI1. The course description emphasizes the outcomes of the study found in Chapter 4 (Analysis and Presentation of Data) and Chapter 5 (Summary, Conclusions, and Recommendations). The system, which is the output of the study, will likewise be checked to support the document claims during the Final Defense.

Upon completion of ITTHESL2, students are expected to achieve specific Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILO) mapped to EARIST Graduate Elements (EDGE). Students should be able to: (1) Explain the theories, concepts, methodologies, and techniques used in the conduct of the study; (2) Develop a logical system that solved the statement of the problem presented in the beginning of the study; and (3) Defend the research paper/thesis successfully, completing the research paper with a well-written manuscript and a 100% functional system. These outcomes map to EDGE attributes such as Problem Analysis (PS), Development of Solutions (DoS), Collaboration & Communication (CaC), and Professionalism and Ethics (PaE).
topic: ITTHESL2 Course Description, Requirements, and Learning Outcomes

content:
The Teaching and Learning Plan for ITTHESL2 outlines the schedule for the first half of the semester. Week 1 is dedicated to Course Orientation and a review of the Institute's VMGO, college goals, and department objectives. Week 2 and Week 3 focus on the submission of Progress Reports and the continued development of the system. In Week 4, students participate in the Actual Demonstration of the System for critiquing .

Week 5 and Week 10 involve the Data Gathering Process, where students identify statistical methods and other data used in the study. Weeks 6-7 continue with System Development (Hardware and/or Software) and further progress reporting and demonstrations. Week 8 involves Approving of Title Proposals (though this seems contextually misplaced for Thesis 2, it is listed in the source). Week 9 is scheduled for the Midterm Examination (Summative Examination).
topic: Weekly Plan: Orientation, System Development, and Midterms

content:
The Teaching and Learning Plan for ITTHESL2 continues from Week 10 through Week 18. Week 10 reiterates the Data Gathering Process. Week 11 focuses on System Development and demonstration for critiquing. Week 12 covers the Statistical Assessment of the System, involving research presentations. Week 13 involves the Tabulation and Presentation of Data .

Week 14 is the deadline for the Submission of completed documents/manuscripts (Chapters 1-5). Weeks 15-16 are dedicated to Research Presentations (Defense) covering Chapters 1 through 5 and PowerPoint presentations. Week 17 is reserved for the final System Demonstration (Hardware and/or Software). The course concludes with the Final Examination in Week 18. Key textbooks include 'Thesis & Dissertation Writing: A Modular Approach' by Tejero and Cachillar.
topic: Weekly Plan: Analysis, Manuscript Submission, and Final Defense

content:
The grading system for the ITTHESL2 course evaluates students through exams, written work, and performance tasks. The Final Rating is calculated as the average of the Midterm Grade (50%) and the Final Grade (50%). The breakdown for each term grade is: Written Work (Homework, Problem Sets, etc.) accounts for 25%; Performance Tasks (Quizzes, Projects, Research Papers, etc.) account for 45%; and Term Assessment (Midterm/Final Exam) accounts for 30% .

The numerical grading scale is as follows: 1.00 (97-100%, Highly Excellent), 1.25 (94-96%, Excellent), 1.50 (91-93%, Very Superior), 1.75 (88-90%, Superior), 2.00 (85-87%, Very Good), 2.25 (82-84%, Good), 2.50 (79-81%, Satisfactory), 2.75 (76-78%, Fair), 3.00 (75%, Passed), and 5.00 (Below 75%, Failed).

Course policies state that English is the language of instruction. Attendance is mandatory, and absence for more than 20% of scheduled hours results in being dropped from the class roll. Regarding Academic Integrity, cheating or plagiarism is treated according to Institute policy, with penalties ranging from failing the assignment to failing the class. Students with disabilities must register with the Office of Student Affairs and Services (OSAS) for accommodations. The syllabus is flexible and subject to change by the instructor with VPAA approval.
topic: Grading System, Rubrics, and Course Policies

content:

The Institute Philosophy states that education is a plexus of knowledge and skills applied to the economic, social, and moral development of a self-actualized and productive citizenry. The Institute Mission is to produce vocationally, technically, technologically, and scientifically trained graduates who are economically productive, self-sufficient, effective, responsible, and disciplined citizens. The Institute Vision envisions EARIST as a center of excellence in trades, business, arts, science, and technology education. The Core Values are Excellence, Accountability, Resourcefulness, Integrity, Service, and Teamwork.

The College of Arts and Sciences (CAS) has specific goals: to develop students' ability to acquire knowledge, think logically, and express themselves creatively with high moral awareness; to encourage students to realize personal and professional goals through self-motivation; to foster lifelong competence and interest in research regarding science, technology, economy, and industry; and to provide avenues for student involvement in extension and production programs. The BS Information Technology Program aims to become globally competent, innovative, socially and ethically responsible, and engaged in lifelong learning endeavors.
topic: EARIST Philosophy, Mission, Vision, Core Values, and CAS Goals

content:
The Bachelor of Science in Information Technology (BSIT) program outlines specific Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO) that graduates must demonstrate. These are categorized into outcomes common to all programs, common to computing disciplines, and specific to the BSIT program.

Graduates must be able to: (1) articulate the latest developments in their specific field of practice; (2) effectively communicate orally and in writing using both English and Filipino; (3) work effectively and independently in multi-disciplinary teams; (4) demonstrate professional, social, and ethical responsibility; and (5) preserve and promote Filipino historical and cultural heritage.

Specific to Computing Studies, graduates must: (1) apply knowledge of computing, science, and mathematics; (2) understand best practices and standards; (3) analyze complex problems and define computing requirements; (4) identify and analyze user needs; (5) design, implement, and evaluate computer-based systems; (6) integrate IT-based solutions; (8) design and develop solutions using a system-level perspective; and (9) utilize modern computing tools.

Specific to BSIT, graduates must: (1) apply knowledge of computing fundamentals and specialization to abstract computing models; (2) solve complex computing problems using fundamental principles of mathematics and computing sciences; (3) apply mathematical foundations and algorithmic principles in modeling and design; (4) understand information security issues; and (5) design and evaluate solutions for complex computing problems considering public health, safety, and environmental factors. Furthermore, graduates must recognize legal, social, ethical, and professional issues involved in the utilization of computer technology.
topic: BS Information Technology Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO)

content:
The course SPISSUES (Social and Professional Issues) is a 3-unit lecture course requiring 3 hours per week. The prerequisite is 4th Year Standing. The course covers an introductory study of the diverse roles computers and information technology play in various societies. It includes analysis and discussion of the social, political, and economic impact of computers and IT, as well as an examination of workplace and ethical dilemmas created by these technologies. It also inquires into the philosophical and psychological implications of new technologies.

Upon completion of SPISSUES, students are expected to achieve specific Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILO) mapped to EARIST Graduate Elements (EDGE). The course aims to develop Problem Analysis, Development of Solutions, Global Citizenship, Collaboration & Communication, Professionalism and Ethics, and Lifelong Learning. Specific topics addressed in the mapping grid include Ethics in the Business World, IT Professionals and IT Users, Internet Crime, Security and Privacy, Intellectual Property, and Software Development. (Note: The source document contains a clerical error listing algorithm-specific outcomes like 'Big O notation' in the CILO section, but the Course Description and Weekly Plan confirm the course content focuses on Ethics and Professional Issues).
topic: SPISSUES Course Description and Learning Outcomes

content:
The Teaching and Learning Plan for SPISSUES outlines the schedule for the first half of the semester. Week 1 covers Course Orientation, VMGO, and Introduction to Ethics and related concepts in IT. Week 2 continues with the Introduction to Ethics. Week 3 focuses on Ethics in the Business World, discussing the importance of fostering good business ethics, improving corporate ethics, and creating an ethical work environment.

Week 4 covers Ethical Decision Making and Ethics in Information Technology. Weeks 5-6 address Ethics for IT Professionals and IT Users, defining the profession, professional codes of ethics, and the ethical behavior of IT professionals. Weeks 7-8 focus on Certification vs. Government Licensing, IT Professional Malpractice, and common ethical issues for IT Users. Week 9 is designated for the Midterm Examination (Summative Examination). Methodologies include interactive learning, type study methods, and multimedia presentations via Google Classroom/Meet.
topic: Weekly Plan: Ethics, Business, Professionals, and Midterms

content:
The Teaching and Learning Plan for SPISSUES continues from Week 10 through Week 18. Weeks 10-11 focus on Computer and Internet Crime, discussing complexity, vulnerability, new risks, and reliance on commercial software. Week 12 covers Software with Known Vulnerabilities, types of attacks, perpetrators, and methods for reducing vulnerabilities (Prevention and Detection Systems).

Weeks 13-14 address Malware damages, combatting malware, Philippine Laws on Computer/Internet Crimes, and Privacy issues (Right of Privacy, Privacy Protection Laws, History of Privacy Protection). Weeks 15-17 cover Intellectual Property, Key Privacy and Anonymity Issues, and Software Development Strategies to engineer quality software. The course concludes with the Final Examination in Week 18. Reference materials include 'Computer Ethics' by Weckert and 'Computer Ethics and Professional Responsibility' by Bynum and Rogerson.
topic: Weekly Plan: Cybercrime, Privacy, Intellectual Property, and Finals

topic: EARIST Philosophy, Mission, Vision, Core Values, and Program Goals

content:
The OBTL Plan for JAVAPLEC outlines the Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO). Although the section header mentions 'Specific to BS Computer Science,' the text states that 'Graduates of BS Information Technology must be able to' demonstrate these outcomes. The outcomes are categorized into common and discipline-specific goals.

Graduates must be able to: (1) articulate the latest developments in their field; (2) communicate effectively in English and Filipino; (3) work effectively in multi-disciplinary teams; (4) demonstrate professional, social, and ethical responsibility; and (5) preserve Filipino historical heritage.

Specific to Computing Studies, graduates must: (6) analyze complex problems and define computing requirements; (7) apply computing knowledge to real-world problems; (8) design and develop solutions using a system-level perspective; (9) utilize modern computing tools; (10) apply knowledge of computing, science, and mathematics; (11) understand best practices and standards; (12) analyze complex problems; (13) identify user needs; (14) design and evaluate computer-based systems; (15) integrate IT-based solutions; (16) apply current techniques and skills; (17) function as a team member or leader; (18) assist in IT project planning; (19) communicate effectively with the computing community; (20) analyze the global impact of computing; (21) understand professional and ethical issues; (22) engage in lifelong learning; and (23) participate in employment and development activities.
topic: Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO)

content:
The course JAVAPLEC (Java Programming Language Lecture) is a 3-unit lecture course with a prerequisite of 'CPROGLEC' (Computer Programming 1). The course description states that it describes the essential concepts necessary for a good understanding of file organization and database management systems, requiring a general understanding of the database environment. It is suitable for students in introductory database classes in computer science.

Upon completion of JAVAPLEC, students are expected to achieve specific Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILO) mapped to EARIST Graduate Elements (EDGE). Students should be able to: (1) Provide updated knowledge in the theories and concepts of computer science using state-of-the-art equipment; (2) Build and strengthen analytical skills by engaging in software development and relevant research through extensive laboratory exercises; (3) Engage with internship programs to showcase skills in computing; and (4) Prepare for advanced studies in Computing Studies/Information Technology. Specific unit objectives include logically analyzing and solving machine problems, skillfully creating application programs using Visual Basic or databases using MS Access/SQL (Note: Context suggests Java, but text mentions VB/SQL), and combining applications to create functional systems.
topic: JAVAPLEC Course Description, Requirements, and Learning Outcomes

content:
The Teaching and Learning Plan for JAVAPLEC covers the first half of the semester from Week 1 to Week 7. Week 1 involves Course Orientation, VMGO discussion, and an 'Overview in Java Programming Language concepts and Its History'. Week 2 focuses on 'Components of Java Programming Language', covering the JDK (Java Development Kit), JVM (Java Virtual Machine), and JRE (Java Runtime Environment). 

Weeks 4-5 (Note: Week 3 is skipped or merged in source context) cover 'C++ vs Java Programming Language' and a deeper dive into 'Java Virtual Machine & its Architecture'. Week 6 introduces 'OOP's Concepts in Java' (Object-Oriented Programming). Week 7 is reserved for the Midterm Examinations. Teaching methodologies include online lectures with video clips, online discussion boards, and modular PDF materials. Assessments include quizzes and online assessments.
topic: Weekly Plan: Java Basics, OOP, and Midterms

content:
The Teaching and Learning Plan for JAVAPLEC continues from Week 8 through Week 15. Week 8 covers 'Java Abstraction', including Abstract Classes, Interfaces, and the difference between Abstract vs Interface. Week 9 focuses on 'Variables and Data Types'. Week 10 covers 'Java Operators', specifically Arithmetic, Relational, and Logical Operators.

Week 11 demonstrates 'Control Statements in Java', followed by 'Loop Statements in Java' in Week 12. Week 13 covers 'Array and String' manipulation. Weeks 14 and 15 are dedicated to 'The Case Study' and 'Final Examination/Final Defense', where students must defend their case study and system. The final defense involves presenting hard-copy and soft-copy documents with system results.
topic: Weekly Plan: Advanced Java Concepts and Final Defense

content:
The grading system for JAVAPLEC calculates the Final Rating as the average of the Midterm Grade (50%) and the Final Grade (50%). The breakdown for term grades is: Written Work (Homework, Module Activities, Quizzes, Research Papers) accounts for 25%; Performance Tasks (Laboratory Activities, Portfolio) account for 45%; and Term Assessment (Midterm/Final Exam) accounts for 30%.

The numerical grading scale is: 1.00 (97-100%, Highly Excellent), 1.25 (94-96%, Excellent), 1.50 (91-93%, Very Superior), 1.75 (88-90%, Superior), 2.00 (85-87%, Very Good), 2.25 (82-84%, Good), 2.50 (79-81%, Satisfactory), 2.75 (76-78%, Fair), 3.00 (75%, Passed), and 5.00 (Below 75%, Failed).

Course policies state that English is the language of instruction. Attendance is mandatory; missing more than 20% of hours results in being dropped. A specific policy mentions 'Laboratory' requirements involving the preparation of Asian dishes (Note: This appears to be an error in the source document, likely copied from a Hospitality Management syllabus, but explicitly present in the text). Academic Integrity policies strictly prohibit cheating and plagiarism. Students with disabilities must register with the OSAS.
topic: Grading System, Rubrics, and Course Policies

content:
The course JAVAPLAB (Java Programming Language Laboratory) is a 1-unit laboratory course with a prerequisite of 'CPROGLAB' (Computer Programming 1). The course description states that it describes the essential concepts necessary for a good understanding of file organization and database management systems, requiring a general understanding of the database environment. It is suitable for students in introductory database classes in computer science .

Upon completion of JAVAPLAB, students are expected to achieve specific Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILO) mapped to EARIST Graduate Elements (EDGE). Students should be able to:
1.  Provide updated knowledge in theories and concepts of computer science using state-of-the-art equipment.
2.  Build and strengthen analytical skills by engaging in software development and relevant research through extensive laboratory exercises.
3.  Engage with internship programs to showcase computing skills and enrich them with practical business training.
4.  Prepare for advanced studies in Computing Studies/Information Technology .

Specific unit objectives emphasized in the mapping grid include: logically analyzing and solving machine problems; skillfully creating application programs using Visual Basic or databases using MS Access or SQL; and combining applications to create functional systems.
topic: JAVAPLAB Course Description, Requirements, and Learning Outcomes

content:
The Teaching and Learning Plan for JAVAPLAB covers the first half of the semester from Week 1 to Week 7.
* **Weeks 1-2:** Orientation, VMGO discussion, and 'Overview in Java Programming Language concepts and Its History'. Activities include reviewing the syllabus and socialized discussion.
* **Week 3:** 'Components of Java Programming Language', covering the JDK (Java Development Kit), JVM (Java Virtual Machine), and JRE (Java Runtime Environment). Students compare different applications among the three.
* **Week 4:** 'C++ vs Java Programming Language'. Students apply knowledge of C++ versus Java .
* **Week 5:** 'Java Virtual Machine & its Architecture' .
* **Week 6:** 'OOP's Concepts in Java' .
* **Week 7:** Midterm Examinations.

Teaching methodologies include online lectures with video clips, online discussion boards, and modular PDF materials. Assessments include individual practical exams, quizzes, and online assessments.
topic: Weekly Plan: Orientation, Java Basics, OOP, and Midterms

content:
The Teaching and Learning Plan for JAVAPLAB continues from Week 8 through Week 14 .
* **Week 8:** 'Java Abstraction', covering Abstract Classes, Interfaces, and the difference between Abstract vs Interface .
* **Week 9:** 'Variables and Data Types', putting them into use through practical exams .
* **Week 10:** 'Java Operators', specifically Arithmetic, Relational, and Logical Operators .
* **Week 11:** 'Control Statements in Java', creating example programs .
* **Week 12:** 'Loop Statements in Java', creating example programs .
* **Week 13:** 'Array and String', utilizing arrays and strings in programs .
* **Week 14:** 'Final Examination/Final Defense', involving the defense of a Case Study and System .

Methodologies include online lectures, video clips, and onsite/online case study defense.
topic: Weekly Plan: Advanced Java Concepts and Final Defense

content:
The grading system for JAVAPLAB calculates the Final Rating as the average of the Midterm Grade (50%) and the Final Grade (50%). The breakdown for term grades is: Written Work (Homework, Module Activities, Quizzes, Research Papers) accounts for 25%; Performance Tasks (Laboratory Activities, Portfolio) account for 45%; and Term Assessment (Midterm/Final Exam) accounts for 30% .

The numerical grading scale is: 1.00 (97-100%, Highly Excellent), 1.25 (94-96%, Excellent), 1.50 (91-93%, Very Superior), 1.75 (88-90%, Superior), 2.00 (85-87%, Very Good), 2.25 (82-84%, Good), 2.50 (79-81%, Satisfactory), 2.75 (76-78%, Fair), 3.00 (75%, Passed), and 5.00 (Below 75%, Failed) .

Course policies state that English is the language of instruction. Attendance is mandatory; missing more than 20% of hours results in being dropped. A Laboratory policy explicitly states: 'Students are required to prepare and present Asian dishes. Exposure in an Interactive Kitchen preferably in an Asian Restaurant/Showcase Preparation and Display of Asian Dishes'. Academic Integrity policies strictly prohibit cheating and plagiarism. Students with disabilities must register with the Office of Student Affairs and Services (OSAS).
topic: Grading System, Rubrics, and Course Policies

content:
According to the Outcome-Based Teaching and Learning (OBTL) Plan for the Information Management course (INFOMGMT), the Eulogio 'Amang' Rodriguez Institute of Science & Technology (EARIST) operates under a defined Philosophy, Mission, and Vision. The Institute Philosophy asserts that education is a plexus of knowledge and skills applied to the economic, social, and moral development of a self-actualized and productive citizenry. The Institute Mission is to produce vocationally, technically, technologically, and scientifically trained graduates who are economically productive, self-sufficient, effective, responsible, and disciplined citizens. The Institute Vision envisions EARIST as a center of excellence in trades, business, arts, science, and technology education. The Core Values are Excellence, Accountability, Resourcefulness, Integrity, Service, and Teamwork.

The College of Arts and Sciences has specific goals: to develop students' ability to acquire knowledge, think logically, and express themselves creatively with high moral awareness; to encourage students to realize personal and professional goals; to foster lifelong competence and interest in research regarding science, technology, economy, and industry; and to provide avenues for student involvement in extension and production programs. The BS Information Technology Program aims to become globally competent, innovative, socially and ethically responsible computing professionals engaged in lifelong learning endeavors.
topic: EARIST Philosophy, Mission, Vision, Core Values, and Program Goals

content:
The OBTL Plan for INFOMGMT outlines the Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO) for the BS Information Technology program. Graduates must be able to: (1) Articulate the latest developments in their specific field of practice; (2) Effectively communicate orally and in writing using both English and Filipino languages; (3) Work effectively and independently in multi-disciplinary and multi-cultural teams; (4) Demonstrate professional, social, and ethical responsibility, especially in practicing intellectual property rights and sustainable development; and (5) Preserve and promote Filipino historical and cultural heritage.

Specific to the Computing Studies Disciplines, graduates must: (6) Analyze complex problems and identify computing requirements; (7) Apply computing knowledge to address real-world problems; (8) Design and develop computing solutions using a system-level perspective; (9) Utilize modern computing tools; (10) Apply knowledge of computing, science, and mathematics; (11) Understand best practices and standards; (12) Analyze complex problems and define computing requirements; (13) Identify and analyze user needs; (14) Design, implement, and evaluate computer-based systems; (15) Integrate IT-based solutions into the user environment; (16) Apply current techniques and skills necessary for the IT profession; (17) Function effectively as a member or leader of a development team; (18) Assist in the creation of an effective IT project plan; (19) Communicate effectively with the computing community; (20) Analyze the logical and global impact of computing; (21) Understand professional, ethical, legal, and security issues; (22) Engage in lifelong learning; (23) Participate in employment and development activities; and (24) Develop competencies to support national, regional, and local development plans.
topic: Program Intended Learning Outcomes (PILO)

content:
The course 'INFOMGMT' (Information Management) is a 3-unit lecture course with a prerequisite of 'INTCOMP' and serves as a prerequisite to 'OOPRGLEC' and 'OOPRGLAB'. The course description involves discussions of applications using web, mobile, and emerging technologies with an emphasis on requirements management, interface design, usability, testing, deployment, including ethical and legal considerations.

Upon completion of INFOMGMT, students are expected to achieve specific Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILO) mapped to EARIST Graduate Elements (EDGE). Students should be able to: (1) Provide skills in electronic encoding, editing, viewing, and printing, including the importation and merging of files; (2) Apply theoretical aspects during hands-on periods; and (3) Operate the computer system using MS Office Excel and PowerPoint. The course topics map to EDGE attributes including Problem Analysis (PS), Development of Solutions (DoS), Global Citizenship (GC), Collaboration & Communication (CaC), Professionalism and Ethics (PaE), and Lifelong Learning (LL).
topic: INFOMGMT Course Description, Requirements, and Learning Outcomes

content:
The Teaching and Learning Plan for INFOMGMT covers the first six weeks with foundational topics. Week 1 focuses on Course Orientation, including the discussion of VMGO, PILOs, and CILOs. Week 2 provides an 'Overview of Information Systems', covering computers in daily life, computer literacy, and transaction processing systems. Week 3, titled 'Computers: The Machine Behind Computing', defines computers, explores their history, hardware, software, operations, and input/output/memory devices.

Week 4 asks 'What is Software?' and covers Computer Languages, Database Systems, Data Warehouses, and Data Marts, including components of a DBMS and recent trends in database design. Weeks 5 and 6 address 'Personal, Legal, Ethical and Organizational Issues of Information Systems', discussing risks, privacy issues, and the impact of IT in the workplace. This period also covers 'Protecting Information Resources', detailing computer and network security, safeguards, security threats, and guidelines for comprehensive security systems. Teaching methodologies include online lectures with video clips, teacher-led discussions, and online assessments.
topic: Weekly Plan: Information Systems Fundamentals and Ethics

content:
The Teaching and Learning Plan for INFOMGMT continues from Week 7 to Week 11. Week 7 covers 'Data Communication', focusing on delivering information anywhere and anytime, basic components of data communication systems, types of networks, and convergence of voice, video, and data. Week 8 explores 'The Internet, Intranets, and Extranets', covering navigation tools, search engines, directories, internet services, web applications, and new trends like Web 2.0 and 3.0.

Week 9 is designated for the Midterm Examination. Weeks 10 and 11 focus on 'E-Commerce' and 'Global Information Systems'. Topics include major categories of E-Commerce (B2C, B2B), mobile and voice-based E-Commerce, and supporting technologies. The section on Global Information Systems discusses why organizations go global, organizational structures, and obstacles to using global information systems. Assessments include online recitations, quizzes, and problem-solving activities.
topic: Weekly Plan: Connectivity, Internet, and E-Commerce

content:
The final phase of the INFOMGMT syllabus spans Weeks 12 through 18. Weeks 12 and 13 focus on 'Building Successful Information Systems', detailing the System Development Life Cycle (SDLC) phases: Planning, Requirements Gathering, Design, Implementation, and Maintenance. This section also covers 'Enterprise Systems' such as Supply Chain Management (SCM), Customer Relationship Management (CRM), Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP), and Knowledge Management.

Weeks 14 and 15 cover 'Management Support Systems', including Decision Support Systems (DSS), Executive Information Systems (EIS), Group Support Systems, and Geographic Information Systems (GIS). It also introduces 'Intelligent Information Systems', covering Artificial Intelligence (AI), Expert Systems, Fuzzy Logic, and Neural Networks. Weeks 16 and 17 address 'Emerging Trends', such as SaaS, Virtual Reality, RFID, Biometrics, and Nanotechnology. Week 18 is reserved for the Final Examination and Final Defense of the Case Study/System.
topic: Weekly Plan: SDLC, Enterprise Systems, and Advanced Technologies

content:
The grading system for INFOMGMT calculates the Final Rating as the average of the Midterm Grade (50%) and the Final Grade (50%). The breakdown for term grades is: Written Work (Homework, Module Activities, Quizzes, Research Papers) accounts for 25%; Performance Tasks (Laboratory Activities, Portfolio) account for 45%; and Term Assessment (Midterm/Final Exam) accounts for 30%.

The numerical grading scale is: 1.00 (97-100%, Highly Excellent), 1.25 (94-96%, Excellent), 1.50 (91-93%, Very Superior), 1.75 (88-90%, Superior), 2.00 (85-87%, Very Good), 2.25 (82-84%, Good), 2.50 (79-81%, Satisfactory), 2.75 (76-78%, Fair), 3.00 (75%, Passed), and 5.00 (Below 75%, Failed).

Course policies state that English is the language of instruction. Attendance is mandatory; missing more than 20% of hours results in being dropped. Academic Integrity policies strictly prohibit cheating and plagiarism. Students with disabilities must register with the OSAS. Note: The syllabus includes a text section regarding 'Laboratory' requirements that states: 'Students are required to prepare and present Asian dishes. Exposure in an Interactive Kitchen preferably in an Asian Restaurant/Showcase Preparation and Display of Asian Dishes.' This appears to be a clerical error in the source document, as it contradicts the IT curriculum context, but it is explicitly present in the text.
topic: Grading System, Rubrics, and Course Policies
